We only decided to check out this place because we happened to be in the area and the name of this restaurant reminds me of a decent restaurant in Hanoi. I was quite concerned when I saw mispelling of the name ( Hà Ni) but the food wasn't as bad as I thought. They use fresh wider noodles which are the ones you'll find in the north of Vietnam, but I felt like there is too much MSG in the broth. The broth is bland and yet too artificially sweet at the same time. However the meat was sliced by a machine so it's thin and quite tender. Not that tasty bun thit nuong (no 31) and goi tom cuon Vietnamese and iced coffee weren't great either. Not coming back.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Came in first and didn't write our names down because there was no line but the lady ended up giving our table to a couple who came in after us. They basically ran out of everything (noodles, rice, meat). I ordered spring rolls and they were by far the worst spring rolls I've ever consumed. 

CUSTOMER SERVICE IS TERRIBLE. Next time you try to talk shit about your customers, be sure they don't understand the language you're talking in. Shouldn't have tipped but against my morals.
author: Polly C.

description: Best soup in the Sunset. #7 and chicken curry are the best! This really is the place to come if you have or are fighting a cold. Their broth is pure magic ! Me and the hubby have been fighting a cold and this soup has been keeping us alive. Shrimp  Spring rolls are bomb too!
author: Roxanne O.

description:
Some friends wanted to get pho and I just simply couldn't say no. 

I got pretty excited about going here because I knew what I wanted to try next: the curry chicken pho. I ordered a small for $7.25 or so.

Curry chicken pho was good. Flavor is different and it's certainly hearty (plentiful potatoes and chicken) but I hated that the chicken is still on the bone. I already have a hard time as it is with chopsticks but CHICKEN ON BONE oh my gosh it was impossible. 

For this reason, I will not order the curry chicken pho again. I like the regular chicken pho just fine as it is.
author: Sofia R.

description: So after many, many, many times of craving their pho ga, I've come to conclusion that whatever I said in my past review from 2009 does not count for anything. This place is delicious and I don't care if people like turtle tower better. It's different! And of course my love for their bun rieu will never die! Love this place and I recommend it to everyone. CASH ONLY by the way!
author: Tiff C.

description:
Quick and easy. Cheap and delicious.

Get the chicken pho or pork vermicelli w/ egg roll dish.

YAAAASSSSS
author: Chris C.

description: Came her around 4-5 ish in the afternoon with barely anybody inside and later on it got busy, I got the rare sliced beef with meatballs and it was pretty good I personally prefer this place better then turtle tower the  broth was very good and the noodles was perfect it was a  Good size and will fill you up, it's cheap and has a lot of parking around the area.
author: Tommy L.

description:
one of my favorite place to get northern pho. been coming here since they opened. the noodles come in small and large size. to me, the small is big enough already but I have seen a lot of people get the large. they must have a huge appetite. 

I always get the chicken with intestines. the rice noodles are smooth and silky, the broth is tasty. plenty amount of tender chicken meat. very comforting food. 

I love the two guys that works there. they always recognize me and chops up the jalapeños for me because I used to peel them by hand into smaller pieces and dose them with fish sauce. gestures like that goes a long way. there is another person there that we miss but no longer works there, Mike was his name. great crew! glad to see they are busy now versus when they first started up. but that means there is a wait. just put your name on the clip board and seatings is pretty quick. staff speaks English and Cantonese.
author: Jules L.

description:
Before Quan Ngon, I had my doubts about Northern-style pho.

I'd tried it on the streets of Hanoi and been unimpressed. Perhaps I'd just grown overly accustomed to the thin rice noodles I grew up eating on Irving Street? In any case, it took me years to finally agree to give Quan Ngon a try.

And I was VERY pleasantly surprised. The broth was super rich and flavorful, even a bit sour in that delicious, vinegary way, and chock full of cilantro and green onions. The noodles -- wider and flatter than traditional Southern pho -- had a very satisfying texture and pull to them. 

The service could be a little faster and more attentive, but other than that, I'm a convert!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Quan Ngon sells hanoi style pho. (no bean sprouts, basil given, just lime wedges) 

eats: rare beef noodle(s. 7.50)
-ho fun noodles used, not reconstituted dried noodles. very slurpy
-rare beef very fresh 
-broth very hot, sweet. some msg used.
3.5 stars

notes:
-everyone spoke cantonese here
-pho comes out fast- a few minutes
-not many options like tripe, tendon, just raw beef, cooked beef, meatballs.
-cash only.
-going to 3 stars since i like thinner noodles, tendons.
author: Victor G.

description:
Steamed surprise.

Find most pho broth to be oily, full of suspect chicken and unmemorable noodles.

Found this pho broth to be light, full of steamed chicken and thick, delicious noodles.

Reasonable $8 plus tax for a small portion that was plenty filling. Service was prompt and friendly. Order was impressively ready in less than five minutes.

No surprise it didn't take much longer to eat it.
author: Jason B.

description: My favorite place for chicken noodle soup. The noodles were very good and the soup was so tasty. I also like the rice plates. Customer service isn't that great but I always come for the food.
author: Caro S.

description:
Definitely a neighborhood gem! ~CASH ONLY~

You MUST get the chicken pho as everyone else mentions! Despite the oil droplets on the surface, the broth tastes so clean. It warms the soul...

At first glance I couldn't believe it was $7.50 for a small, but their portions make up for the price. A small was more than enough to fill my stomach, and definitely comparable to a med-large at Kevin's Noodle House.

Only complaint is that they don't serve it with a plate of mint, basil, and bean sprouts, so I guess this constitutes as Northern style? However, they DO have sriracha and the hoisin sauce, which is enough for me!

SERVICE: Hit or miss. There was only one guy serving the entire room.

Will definitely be back.
author: Jenna H.

description:
Best chicken pho I've had in the Bay Area. I'm glad it's near where I live and the majority of people don't like to come out to the sunset area or this place will have an endless line. 

I got a small bowl of pho ga (chicken pho) and it was a perfect size to satisfy my appetite. I was surprised it came with a thicker flat noodle instead of the usual vermicelli noodle. The soup is just right when you can finish the soup and not have to chug a few gallon of water. Add a squeeze of lime and a few bites of jalapeños and you got a complete meal. 

They brought me hot tea right as I sat down, but I noticed they brought water for a different table. So ask for whatever they don't give you if you want it.
author: Michael S.

description:
As a Vietnamese person who grew up with a fair amount of northern-style cuisine, I would be remiss if I didn't point out some important differences from more common styles of pho. 

Someone people here are ignorant of the fact that some northern pho places don't serve veggies. Also, some pho items come with the large, flat noodles known as "hu tieu" in Vietnamese, or "ho fun" in Chinese. That's just the style so you really can't detract a star. The northern style focuses more on the simplicity and clarity of the broth. 

I wish more people would post fully informed reviews about cuisine style so that it's an accurate representation. 

As for this restaurant, it is a decent place that'll do the trick. Turtle Tower is still probably better, but it was so long since I've been. Supposedly, the one in the Tenderloin is the best.  My Vietnamese friends generally prefer TT, but I think that's more for the beef pho.  I really need to revisit one. However, today at QN, it's pho ga day and this curry one is hitting the spot :)
author: Dylan T.

description: Food is awesome, northern style pho with tons of locals.  Large chicken pho is the same size as small, so just get the small (I have a picture to prove it).   On a side note though, is seeing a bunch of cantonese speaking people in a vietnamese restaurant what lends to it's credibility?  That is like saying seeing 'americans' in a mexican restaurant gives credibility to it.  Just a thought.
author: Choladeva C.

description:
A local's spot for sure.  Lines get rather long here especially during the prime time hours on the weekends.  If you have heard of or been to Turtle Tower, then  this needs to be the next stop for possibly one of the best spots in SF for a northern Vietnamese style Pho Ga aka Chicken Pho.  Their soup base does, however, have MSG.  That doesn't stop the zealous locals from coming back on the regular.  The chicken is never overcooked here, and the light chicken broth is like the gift from the gods especially after a night of alky overdose.  If you like chicken innards, then you can get that with your chicken pho as well.  Just can't go wrong with that crunchy bite of gizzard contrasting the soft silky bite of wide rice noodles.  For the spicy lovers out there, don't forget to dash on that ridiculously tantalizing house blend of tongue zapping, tear jerking, fire breathing chili sauce.  I'm not sure what they put in it but I do believe I taste habanero.  I've never had crack before but I can empathize with those addicts through this crazy good sauce.

Although they are well known for their chicken pho, their other options could equally steal the show depending on what you're craving on a particular day.  They have a wonderfully done fall off the bones tender ox tail noodle in a red wine soup.  Hard to find great ox tail done right here in the city.  They make it perfect here.  I want to say that is one of my faves, but let's face it, I have many faves here.  

There's the Satay Beef Noodle Soup flavored with a bold peanutty satay sauce, topped with thick slices of rare beef that slowly cooks in the hot broth.  I like to take those out when they look med rare so they don't get too cooked, and dip them back into the broth when I'm ready to eat each slice with my noodles. 

The Bun Rieu is so addictive!  This traditional noodle soup uses tomato, shrimp paste, shrimp, crab, and crab paste as base.  It is served with soft tasty meat balls made from pork, shrimp, and crab with silky bites of vermicelli noodles.  If you are feeling adventurous, ask for extra shrimp paste, mix that with lime juice and chili sauce, and add that to every spoonful of noodle.  My friends from Vietnam do that, and it is to die for.  

My last fave here is the Curry Chicken Noodle Soup.  Perhaps the best in the city in my books.  What makes them so much better than any other spot is the free range chicken they use.  It's not shredded chicken like the chicken that comes with the Chicken Pho they are known for, but actual pieces of chopped chicken along with the bones.  The flavor of the chicken soup is enhanced by the curry and softened with coconut milk.  Cilantro and onions make the perfect toppings brightening the flavor altogether.  I like to add extra cilantro.  Too good.  Way too good.

Those are my go tos.  Any time I take a seat there, I accept the fact that I am no longer the boss. If it were up to me, I'd sit there indecisive, and probably order all of it just so I can get a few bites of each.  That proved damaging to my pockets at one point in time.  It was the right choice for me to give up my decision making to my board of directors while I'm there.  What I order solely depends on the demands of my belly, my cravings, and my gf.  I trust they know what I want, and they get it right every time.

Remember, a dash of their house made chili sauce to every bite will change your life forever... You will give up Sriracha while you are here like I did.  Now isn't that life changing enough?
author: Colin M.

description:
I was craving pho & this place definitely satisfied just that.

I came here with a few friends and we all ordered regular pho with a variety of meats. The noodles here are thicker than the ones I'm used to but it didn't bother me. The noodles were cooked well & the soup was delicious. 

The reason for -1 star is because this is the first pho place I've ever been to that doesn't give raw onions and bean sprouts. 

Other than that, I will be back if I'm ever in SF craving pho!
author: Christine L.

description:
CONSISTENCY IS KEY. 
And this place has shown consistency throughout the years.
Always a dependable place for a quick meal and I swear by this place. 
I honestly do not know why people insist on going to turtle tower.

SOME FAVORITES :
- "#7 Large dark meat" Chicken ho fun, a mf*ckin' classic. YOU CAN'T GO WRONG.
- Beef pho, I'm not sure if they use a different cut of beef but it's so much more tender than other typical beef.
- Curry chicken ho fun : CREAMY GOODNESS, HOLY SCHMOKES! Sometimes I ask to substitute their default bone in chicken with the chicken from the chicken noodle.
- Oxtail red wine noodle soup
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Like Turtle Tower, this is Northern Style Vietnamese Pho. The noodles are thicker and they do not provide you with bean sprouts, basil or hoisin sauce (although they do provide hoisin sauce here). 

I thought it was very good, I ordered #10 (rare steak & well done steak), but I like my meat more on the medium/med-well side so the broth was not hot enough to cook my rare steak all the way through. So unless you like your meat on the rare/med-rare side, this isn't really a dish for you-get the chicken or well done steak pho instead. My boyfriend got the 5-spice chicken rice plate and he said it was very good. I tried one of this egg rolls and they do it just right, very crispy and crunchy!

As for payment.. The bill came out to be $22.50-ish (we got soymilk & thai iced tea too), I gave them $40 cash, and we waited a very long time to get the change back. After asking for the change again, 3 of the employees started pointing and yelling at each other. When we we asked for the check a different waitress had given our check, and our waiter (the original guy) picked up the check. Apparently one of the girls gave our change to a different customer and they walked out with our money. They still reimbursed us and gave us the correct amount of change, but just make sure to keep an eye on who they give the change to..
author: Mimi C.

description: Solid chicken pho and I think that the hot sauce (home made apparently) is pretty bomb.
author: Chris T.

description: If I could give this no stars I would, but Don't come here. The old Asian lady is rude as fuck. If you're going to work at  a restaurant, learn good customer service.
author: Helen D.

description:
I know there is a Turtle Tower cult out here in SF, so I'm a little scared to say this but I think Quan Ngon rocks my socks better than Turtle Tower. There, I said it. Please don't throw red paint at me. 

I first discovered pho ga while living in SoCal. It's very hard to top Vietnamese food coming from the heart of Little Saigon but I must say that Quan Ngon earned itself a spot near the top amongst my favorites. The flavor and clarity of the broth is what gets me and I like the fact that I can request for all white meat. I can always devour my bowl of piping hot pho ga within minutes and trust that I leave no noodle behind. 

If you're not in the mood for pho ga or you want more than just one item then I recommend the following dishes:

1. Imperial rolls - crispy and served with cold noodles that you can dip in nuoc mam (fish sauce)

2. Bun rieu - not as good as Loi's but not bad either

3. Curry chicken served with a fresh baguette - the potatoes are to die for and I love dunking the warm and fresh baguette into the delicious curry

That pretty much sums up the extend of my experience with the menu at Quan Ngon. Judging by how pack this restaurant gets, I can only guess the rest of the menu is just as delicious and satisfying.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Zero stars. I think this place changed owners. Not even vietnamese ppl that work here. 90 percent of the food we wanted to order was not available, the waitress also said that the raw beef salad we ordered will have to take 20+ minutes....raw beef....how can that take 20+ minutes?? What they gotta do? Go and kill the cow?

During our meal, the waitress started taking away the hoisin sauce and started to clean our table before we were finished. 

She then added a 15% tip when no tip should be given for this lousy place. 

Cliff notes:
-Cup of noodles is more authentic than this place.
-a bum can provide better service
author: Melanie N.

description: Good Vietnamese restaurant in the sunset district. They have good bun cha and bun rieu, but their best dish is the chicken noodle soup.
author: Peter K.

description:
I like the good Raw/Rare beef noodle soup. I guess it was number 61 or 62.  I did not get the tendons and beef balls though.  Something about that beefball makes me weary. But they do do give you alot of beef. So, that's a plus. 

It's not too expensive, which is why Im going to be back.
author: Selby C.

description:
Sadly this place has the worst service. I waited for 10 minutes to be helped. The staff is not very friendly and seems very occupied with other matters. 

The food is ok, very blan and not the most flavorful. My best advise is go somewhere else for pho.
author: Angel K.

description:
I had expected really authentic pho because this is an area where a lot of Asian restaurants are concentrated. It was okay. My friend ordered chicken over rice and it was lukewarm...
I was surprised many customers were there and the servers were not friendly.
author: Kaori M.

description:
In love with this place. Sorry turtle tower, I change my heart. 
Great friendly service with better chicken pho. 
I haven't try other pho in this restaurant. This review is 100% base on many bowls of chicken pho that I had. 

They put a lots of onions, cilantro to add on flavor. Pho is so tender, soft, just right texture. 
Haven't have any bad, diluted soup at all. Always full flavored. 

Side dish, fried tofu is also good. Crispy, crispy, crispy but not greasy. 

I'm going to have pho ga again tomorrow!
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I love number 11 "rare beef and beef ball",  the reason I gave this place 5 star for 

1.their tasty soup base  
2. tender beef ball 
3. less MSG than similar North Vietnamese Pho ( famous one in downtown sf )
4.  I also their steam chicken, it not too expensive with good portion, an ideal side order when you are hungry + with a friend or family ;) see my picture
author: Quan T.

description: I like it here because they don't give me a hard time for ordering the chicken pho without skin. Their noodles are super soft and slippery- even when reheated for takeout. The broth in clean and clear- just the way I like it. Cash only though so keep that in mind!
author: Cynthia J.

description:
Food is good. No doubt about it. But, boy are they stingy with their hot sauce and hoisin sauce when you order take out!

I ordered 3 orders of noodles and the lady only gave me one sauce for the 3 orders. When I asked for 2 more, she was so rude and made a comment that the one sauce she gave me was enough!  I didn't like that I had to explain to her why I needed 3 individual sauces. It should be a no brainer that the sauces should accompany each order.
author: Joanie S.

description: This place went downhill. Need to clean the place up. Food isnt tasting as fresh. Comes no where close to turtle tower
author: Justin C.

description:
This is my favorite pho place hands down! I forgot the exact number I got but it is the Pho Bo Dac Biet, which is the combo of well done, beef balls, and rare beef in a beef noodle soup. My mouth is watering right now as I write this review. I got the large portion since I was starving. The noodles are not like the usual thin rice noodles, but are the wider ones.  The meat is SO TENDER. I usually do not like to get beef balls but this place is the only exception. The beef balls are extremely flavorful and I can tell that they are more expensive and are of better quality than the ones that other places offer. 
The place is usually crowded with a short wait. During those rush hours, the service might be a tad bit slow. I remember I had to wait about 10 minutes to finally have a waiter come and take our order. However, the food came quickly! Of course, each table is stocked with hoisin and sriracha sauces. They are a must when eating pho!
author: Sam L.

description: Came here pretty frequently here until today. I found a fly in my pho. It really turned me off and I probably won't be coming back.
author: Steven B.

description: The best chicken pho EVER! Generous amount of chicken. The broth is super tasty and noodles are always the right texture. I am not sure what kind of hot sauce they have on the table, I believe they make their own, but it is the best! It goes really well with the chicken pho. The spring rolls here are pretty good too. I feel like it's a little different from every place else because they add mint in there. If you are planning to go for dinner, make sure to go at least by 7 because they usually sell out of their chicken pho.
author: Al H.

description: This is a smaller, no frills, cash only spot. Service is friendly, and turnaround is quick. The tabletops are coated with a slightly sticky film, and on colder days, your clothes will pick up the aromas in the restaurant. Food-wise, their noodles are the flat rice ones. The pho ga here is on point (delicious broth that actually takes like chicken--IMO, it's better than Turtle Tower's).
author: Andrew L.

description:
A cold cold day in SF, so I went to Quan Ngon and had lunch with the best person in the world, ME!

Extremely happy that they had bun rieu on the menu. Quick, light and comforting is what I like.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Solid chicken noodle soup (Pho Ga). Juicy tender chicken + rich chicken broth. Another great Sunset neighborhood joint.
author: Nop J.

description: Quan Ngon is bf's go-to place for pho in the Sunset. I've eaten there 3 times so far. Twice I've had the pho and once the bun rieu. It's good for what it is and satisfies. I'm not sure how authentic it is bc the staff/owners are always speaking Cantonese. Bf says restroom is not that clean. Yesterday we saw a giant mosquito just chillin on the wall inside. I guess mosquitos like pho too.
author: Liv A.

description: I like their chicken pho but then again I think all pho places taste the same. No offense.  Decent place if you want a quick pho fix.  The only thing kinda gross about this place is that their menus are sticky. I do not want to touch your sticky menus.
author: Mauricia L.

description:
Highly disappointed. My girlfriend and I had come in one time before and ate in and had a fine experience cheap fast and delicious just what I want from a Pho place. 

That being said we ordered take out a couple weeks later and despite us stating the name of the soup we were given the wrong order , no big deal mistakes happen so I went back and told them the error now this is where it gets out of hand. 

Not only was I treated in a very rude way the hostesses argued with me and accused me of ordering the wrong thing. They would not change our order and instead gave me a side of beef that was really only enough for one order and when I got home I noticed it was still frozen!

Needless to say I have gone to many Pho places and I have never been treated so rudely and sadly I  will not be coming back here again.
author: Marcus K.

description:
Cash Only. Two items here are worth going all the way to the Outer Sunset: Bun Rieu has a nice balance of tomatoes and crab meat paste. The egg/crab meat chunks break down easily and is not too salty. The broth is not thick. Also, it's a testament that it's sold out on some visits.

The other item is Pho Ga Long Me Trung Non, using the larger rice noodles, with shredded chicken and quail eggs. The broth is fine by itself, no need to add anything except maybe hot sauce. Alas, it no longer comes with "goi ga"=chicken slices/shredded over chopped cabbage, and a ginger/fish sauce for dipping.

Otherwise, the menu is not that big and there are handwritten specials posted. They also have a hot chili oil sauce that's quite spicy but fits with whatever is served

Located in the Outer Sunset, so it's not convenient to go to from other parts of the City. Parking could be hit or miss, but is usually a miss during dinner hours in this area.

But beware, the place is cold and breezy - as it has been for years! Their vent "window" above the front door has gaps in the glass and cold air shoots in constantly. Many people kept their coats on while inside.
author: Peter L.

description:
(See pic)

I love this neighborhood where you have 1 or 2 establishments for each kind of food and all of them are with great great quality.

And I love this place as it has Bun Rieu! Learned about this dish from Yelper Peter L but not a lot of places serve it. So when I saw it on the menu I knew I had to have it, especially since it's drizzling chilly outside.

What better than a hot bowl of tomato soup with some very easily soft tender broken apart crab meatballs. It came with a side of shredded cabbage and mint leaves.
author: T L.

description: Had the Rare Beef Pho for a quick lunch...oh my god, the beef is so mind-numbingly tender! I've never had it like this before. As always, there is a good amount of noodles and the broth is very tasty. I also always opt for the soft tofu puree drink. It's pretty unique. And its so simple: sweet tofu, coconut milk, ice. Yum!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I love this place. And I would come here much more frequently if my mother doesn't cook the exact same thing at home. Heh.

Things people need to know about the must-haves of good chicken pho:
Clear broth, but flavorful.
Flavorful, but you don't need to drink a whole gallon of water two hours after your meal.
Fresh noodles (smooooooth, not too soft not too hard, and not broken up like baby food)  that aren't pre-cooked and waiting, all balled up in the bottom of your soup--which by the time you break it apart, your soup is all milky. Ick.
Yummy chicken! Not crappy dry chicken breast (unless you're into that).

And believe it or not...this restaurant can make my perfect bowl of Pho Ga! ..even better than the famous Turtle Tower's :x (But of course, still second to my mother's.)
author: Athena L.

description:
No, it's not better than Turtle Tower. 

Very onion-y, not very salty. But the chicken here is crazy tender!
author: Jess C.

description:
Very surprised how good this place was. I was too lazy to go all the way to kevin's on Irving. So happy that I did. I think this place is much better than kevin's.
Their pho ga (chicken pho) was excellent. I almost liked it better than their pho bo.  And I never say that about chicken over beef. Their rare beef pho bo was so good though. Tender slices of good cut beef. A little bit thicker sliced than normal. But that what actually makes it better. I'll def go back especially since it's closer. And easier to park than Irving.
author: Augusto M.

description: Was feeling a wee bit under the weather & the Pho Ga here saved my life!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Oh yes! Great Pho Ga (the chicken variety of soup) here. The cabbage and chicken salad that I love so much is solid here too. 

They have two sizes for their pho...small and large. We each had a small and the chicken salad which was effing huge. 

My one and only complaint isn't really a complaint...the chicken has skin on it. And, there are some less than perfect slices in there too. But, I get it.  This is the real thing. It's authentic damnit! But, I'm a spoiled little gringo from the suburbs. And, I want the super pristine white breast meat. I'm going to have to get over that shiz. 

Oh, the noodles are a little different here than most of the angel hair style that I'm used to. These are the wider style rice noodles. 

I will certainly come back here...22$ for two small soups with a very large salad.  That is some great value.
author: Dusty B.

description: This place is a gem in the sunset. I go there for the beef pho and I'm never disappointed. I can say it's in my top 3 best pho places. The broth is flavorful but not so much that you can't season to your liking without ruining the soup. They have all the needed condiments (sriracha, chili, chili vinegar, hoisin). It comes out steaming hot, with the beef slowly cooking atop the noodles. I've noticed they aren't always consistent with the noodles; sometimes they are the wide flat ones (that you might find in Thai khaosoy), sometimes "standard" thin ones seen in most traditional pho. Either way, both varieties make an enjoyable dish. The service is quick and satisfactory. They only accept cash. I only wished I lived closer so I could come every weekend.
author: Anna S.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend after I whined to him about my pho cravings.

I am so glad we came because this place had some bomb a** pho ga! In my opinion, bay area's best chicken noodle soup. 

Four stars because it was cold as hell inside, and the Thai tea+peach puree was blehhh
And where my bean sprouts at?! 

I'll most definitely come back whenever I'm craving pho ga!
author: Tracy V.

description: Definitely the best phô I've ever had. And the waiter was super quick with the delicious tea. Totally worth the drive.
author: Erik N.

description:
Ordered up the Number 13 today, which is the Bun Rieu.
Full of flavor today, it did not need any fish sauce.
Pretty damn satisfying as I left full.
...and I still had a few minutes lleft on the parking meter.
...not today o' cursed DPT!. 
.../fistpump!!
author: Derek N.

description: Wow this place has changed. Rude rude rude!!! The waitress are rude. I walked in asking if I need to sign in. And the waitress was like, "Of course you need to sign in, I don't keep track of people." The food taste like msg. I have to drink a bottle of water to wash it down. cash only, no ATM!! Will not go back.
author: Michael Q.

description:
This is definitely my go-to chicken noodle joint in the entire Bay Area !!

I love the Pho Ga because they give you the perfect mix of dark and white meat, shredded to thin boneless strips. The broth is light, yet fragrant. And the noodles are slightly thicker than your normal pho (resembles chinese ho fun) and they are cooked to just the right consistency. I come here when I'm homesick and get the noodles to go when i'm sick-sick. This bowl of brothy wonders seriously warms the soul !
author: Kelly Y.

description: My favorite place to go on a cold day or when I'm feeling under the weather.  The pho ga is the perfect cure for any sickness. I found to like their pho ga better than turtle towers. They have a really good Vietnamese iced coffee too.
author: Linz C.

description:
Quan Ngon is popular for their northern style chicken noodle soup but I don't think their broth is nearly as good as Turtle Tower in TL. But it's decent, convenient and most importantly it's gotten better. I remember when they first opened, they used tons of MSG in their broth. I will literally fall into food coma right after and will wake up super thirsty like a mofo. 

So what else is good here? The beef noodle soup with the rare beef on the side. Their meat is very tender and fresh.  Raw beef salad is also good here and the slices are not too thick.  

For something different, try the curry chicken noodle soup. Broth is very light and sweet.  They use fresh chicken chopped into bite size pieces including the skin & bone. This is why it's very tender and juicy. If you don't like chicken skin or don't want to deal with bones, don't order this.  

Cash only.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I love the chicken noodle soup! Super delicious. Only complain I have is that there is not much of a difference from a small and a large when you order togo. I feel that they are the same size. I only dine in one time. Someone dropped the whole batch of chopsticks from the table and when they picked it back up the waiter added them to the dirty dishes bucket. It made me really happy that they didnt just take it back somewhere and possibly reuse it without being washed. 

#7 is my favorite but it can use more chicken and less noodle on the small. I love the taste of the soup too!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Food is top notch. Fish cakes have a nice grill taste, it does not even need the dipping sauce, and the dish even comes with noodles & veggies. The chicken curry noodle soup is not too thick & not watery, the yellow curry flavor is delicious, the potatoes are from heaven, but the chicken has bone still. Normal Vietnamese prices, $8-$12 a plate. The restaurant is clean, the service is great, food comes out in 5 min, I will return, i highly recommend...
author: Mono L.

description: Delicious option for northern style pho. Tasty chicken pho, yummy fresh spring rolls and speedy service. Dine in if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Heather R.

description:
In sum: Affordable northern Vietnamese restaurant with tasty food and terribly rude service. 

Ordered the wine sauce oxtail pho and the rare beef pho. Wine sauce oxtail broth was incredibly delicious, broth was rich and flavorful and the oxtail was tender and cooked perfectly. This soup is rare and unique, overly impressed. Pho tái (rare beef) was  well executed. Flavorful broth and I liked their use of medium rice noodles in both soups, which is different, and had a perfect texture and consistency. Not too chewy, stuck together, or overcooked and soft. The chili oil on the side is a good addition if you are looking for spice and a little more flavor. The condiments and sauces provided on the table of Vietnamese restaurants may be a good indicator of how authentic or good the food is, and I was pleased to see that there was no shitty Hoisin or oyster sauce in sight for people to dump and destroy their pho with. 

Also ordered the imperial rolls. Crunchy, well seasoned filling, pickled daikon and carrot and noodles provided as should be, and cheap. 

As many of my experiences in Vietnamese restaurants, service was terrible. People are unhelpful, don't acknowledge you whatsoever, and randomly charge you for things I'd never been charged for before. Had to yell across the restaurant for my servers attention, unsure if she heard me but asked anyway for a takeaway container for my soup, and five minutes later handed me a cardboard box. I pointed to my soup and said I needed a plastic container, and after grumpily going back to get one she grabs our check that she already handed us to change our total price because apparently it's extra cost to ask for a container to take your leftovers home. I don't really mind paying for the plastic... But she was extraordinarily rude about it and didn't communicate so. *shrug. Fortunately for this place I'm not one of those amateur yelp reviewers that base my under $30 Asian food restaurant experience on their below stellar service. But just wanted to vent because it always leaves a bad taste in my mouth. 

At least the food didn't :)
author: Andrea D.

description: Overall, the food is good here. I ordered a BBQ pork spring roll, Combo beef pho, and a vegetable pho here for take out. The BBQ pork spring roll was delicious, wrapped very nicely with BBQ pork (not a lot of fat), vermicelli, and lettuce. The roll had like 85% vermicelli, which I don't mind because I love it. The vegetable pho had tofu, tomatoes, and a few other vegetables; the chicken broth was very good after adding lime juice. The beef in the combo beef pho was good but it didn't come with a lot of variety or amount of beef. There was only two meatballs and slices of beef.
author: Betty C.

description:
They may be known for their chicken pho but their beef pho is the best I've had. It's northern style so it's a little different from the typical pho we are used to but it's damn good! Seriously, I have yet to find a beef broth that taste as good as they make it here.

Like some reviews have said, this place is WAY better than Turtle Tower.

Get the three color drink, they blend the ice with coconut milk. It's awesome!
author: Andy W.

description:
Three stars for delicious pho, however the service (or lack of) is disappointing.

Quan Ngon is a perfect place to grab a quick, light lunch with the large bowl being more than enough for two to share. 

Pho utilizes rice noodles which make it a great bowl of gluten-free goodness! 

Finding parking is a pain, I would recommend parking in the residential areas if you don't want metered parking.
author: Juliette R.

description: I have to give this place a 0 star. The waiter had completely poor customer service. I went with a friend and ordered the pho ga. The order came in 10 minutes but there's a fly in it. I tell the waiter and he asked if I want to order something else. Yeahhhhhh... Right... I think I'd rather take my money elsewhere then risk having food poisoning from this place. My recommendation is to skip on this one.
author: Alice C.

description: Pho ga is legit. Service was a bit on the slow side. Spring rolls had Chinese style wrapper. Waited a few minutes to seat our table of 6. Water refilling was on the slow side. The orange chili garlic sauce is super spicy. The large was huge. The broth is on point. The noodles were a bit overcooked.
author: Alan H.

description:
The 3 stars is for its outstanding foods. I agree with other negative comments on its service. I literally stood, and waited to be seated 10 mins when there were plenty of empty seats and nobody cared about even taking care of me. 

They seem to be really nice to Cantonese customers and tend to ignore others. Price is reasonably okay.
author: Robert C.

description: Pho is not normal pho noodles.  I was  unpleasantly surprised by the different noodles.  But it's good noodles.  Tables were a bit sticky.
author: Byron L.

description: Usually dont like northern vietnamese food but this place is decently good! I enjoy it! cept Its cash only...
author: d n.

description:
Although I had a good experience the first time, after coming back 2 more times, the service declined. 

The to-go pho seems to be smaller and smaller each time, even when you order the 'large size'. 

Would not come back, go to PHH 2 - Kevin's Noodle House on Irving instead.
author: Alissa M.

description: My favorite place to get bun rieu! I recommend to come here during lunch or early dinner. Sometimes they run out or it tastes kinda diluted towards the end of the night which can be understandable.
author: Sherry H.

description:
We ordered a small and large chicken pho, large special pho, small rare beef+beef balls pho. 

Good:
- Thicker noodles so I assume they are fresh like the ones you order from SoCal 
- White meat chicken was good. 

Bad:
- We asked for no skin on the chicken and that went on deaf's ears. 
- The beef pho was mediocre and doesn't have the aroma that you come to expect with legit pho and I don't care if it's from the north or south region. Should have some flavor. 
- The beef was not as fresh. 
- No bean sprouts or basils. That's a big WTH!  The staff said it's because it's northern region pho. Whatever. When hamburgers were invented, no ketchup was used, but you don't see people leaving out ketchup (leave it as an optional condiment).  The sign says nothing about Northern noodles. It's just Quan Ngon, noodle house. The sign on the window shows bowls of noodles with basils and sprout plate next to the bowl.  Total load of crock.
author: Anh L.

description:
The background: "Quan Ngon" quite literally translates to tasty restaurant in Vietnamese. The name does hold true to this little Vietnamese restaurant nestled in the outer sunset. They've got a smaller Vietnamese menu, but it'll hit all the sweet spots. 

The details: This restaurant is my go to for chicken Pho. Clear, flavorful, non msg loaded broth, basic but all that is needed!  White meat chicken with various chicken organs (gizzards and the like) in a bowl loaded with noodles sprinkled with bean sprouts and basil = heaven pho sure! 

The verdict: Come here on a rainy, foggy, cold day and you'll be a happy camper. So basically come here any sf day!
author: Christine B.

description: Hands down the best noodle soup I have had in SF. The staff are friendly, the food is fresh and delicious, the spring rolls are amazing, the chicken salad is, their hot sauce is amazing, their peanut sauce is amazing, and the menu has ox tail soup. I couldn't ask for anything more.
author: Jeremiah B.

description:
I'm hungover as shit... This was probably the MOST satisfying remedy I've ever had. Piping hot soup, pho tai and tendon beef balls :). Service is FAST and great. 
The beef is not the best quality... But they play good Asian music, so 5 stars.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Pho ga is okay. It's doable when you are hungover, not as good as TT.
shredded chicken salad is good - big order!
beef carpaccio - you can't really mess that up.

FAV thing - red wine oxtail noodle soup with ho fun! I like ho fun and i love oxtail! That's definitely something I would get here every time!
author: Mindy C.

description: I've tried a few pho places in the city, and was a little skeptical about trying this one but I liked it! Between my friends and I, we tried the Bun Rieu and beef pho. I was pleasantly surprised at the flavor of the broth! I did like the beef pho more, as I didn't feel as if the bun rieu had enough flavor to it. I would definitely come back though, for a quick cheap meal in the city!
author: Winnie T.

description: Bad service!  If they are busy they don't really care!  I was just trying to get to-go.  They weren't paying attention to me so I went across the street!
author: Jake S.

description: Good is good but service kills it. Man and old women are very rude and demanded tip then added 4$ on to my bill. Very unsatisfying
author: Annikka S.

description: We walked in at 8pm and although they don't close until 9:30pm, we were rudely told they were all closed, even though the lights were on and multiple Asian families were enjoying dinner. We were also told they sold out of everything which seems highly unlikely as we could see food in the back. This has been a spot we've enjoyed in the past but will likely not return to in the future. It seems the staff has a certain bias towards some customers and clearly we're not in their favor.
author: Geoffrey G.

description:
Great food - I had the Bun with Pork & Egg Roll - definitely recommend. 

The service wasn't great, took me a while to get a drink. 

Traditional food, delicious and cheap.
author: Catherine M.

description: Have only gotten take out once and got the duck pho with the pork and rice. Best rice noodles I have gotten since I have been living in SF for a year. They give you a lot of meat which is rare to come by. Wish I had known about this place sooner! And super cheap for the amount of food.
author: Kk S.

description:
My friend and I decided to try this place out for the first time...didn't even check yelp reviews or anything.  To my surprise, ti was good.

I ordered the pho ga (chicken noodle soup), which I found out later that is what they are known for.  When the food came, I thought it be the thin rice noodles but it was thick rice noodles (it was between a rice noodle and chow fun noodle).  I liked the soup base as it was mixed with onions and cilantro in it.  The chicken was tasty and tender.

I good place for those who want chicken noodle pho (thick noodle tho).
author: James L.

description:
This place is killer. Austere in ambiance is an understatement, but who needs that when you are served the best pho in the city, and trust me, I have tried them all. Here are the reasons I will never find better:

1. the broth - the tastiest, funked out, marrow tasting broth I have found

2. the noodles - the flat noodle vermicelli is awesome. so much more taste than it's round, skinny-noodled cousin. it just sucks up all the flavor

3. service - always a smile, and a 'how's it going boss.' dope

4. the tendon - beef balls without, are for the uninitiated. here, clean, fresh, and chewy

5. the chili sauce - OMG, does any pho joint have better?? none. it's oily, home made (no sanibel paste), so hot, so damn hot, it caused me to enjoy spicy food. I've converted to Quan Ngon as a religion ever since

5. tartare - try the tartare app. meatlicious

6. price - leave rotund, with lunch for two, for around $20. pocketlicious

In compendium, I come here 2-3 times a week for a reason: to sweat 'n slurp
author: J H.

description:
Service: 5/5
Food: 5/5
Wait: 3/5
Price: $
Portions: 5/5
Presentation of food: 3/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3.5/5
Overall: 5/5

Came here for the first time recently, I personally am a big fan of Ho Fun type noodles; and they make their own fresh batch every day. I AM IMPRESSED, you can taste it in the noodles. I had their beef pho which was amazing. I will definitely come back and try the chicken noodle (Pho Ga) next, I heard great things. Also their Fried Pork spring rolls were super yummy! Highly reccomend!
author: Eva H.

description:
Ordered the five spice chicken rice dish. This place could've easily been 4 stars based on the fews bites I took. Upon first getting my dish and shifting the food around, I found an inch long black hair than was seared into the skin of the chicken (meaning it was there before cooking). I picked it out and tossed that piece to the side and continued eating. One hair probably doesn't deserve 1 star even though I should've returned the dish after that. I found 4 hairs total of decent length. I became sick to the stomach and flagged down a waitress. I wanted the dish off the bill because I lost my appetite and wanted to leave. She kept on insisting (for a good minute or 2) that I order something else to replace that dish like a nagging car salesman only concerned about being paid. Grossed out and insulted, I just got whatever my girlfriend ordered and took it to go.  

It's disappointed because the food was actually decent but no one should ever discover more than one hair in a single order.
author: Dominic L.

description: Ahhhh !! I absolutely love their Chicken Pho. ESPECIALLY after a night of drinking.  They give a generous amount of chicken.  I love love love their orange hot sauce too! Whenever I crave Chicken Pho, this is the place to go.  However, I do feel like they have msg in the broth because I get so thirsty after eating it.
author: Emi K.

description: Order spring rolls from here and there was a cockroach leg stuck to it!!! I made sure I wasn't mistaking it for something else. It was a cockroach leg. Or a leg of a bug cuhs it had small little hair things to the leg...EWWWWWW wish I got a picture to show for it. Disgusted and never coming back!
author: Kaman C.

description:
Basic Vietnamese pho joint that serves northern style pho which are the wider pho rice noodles. Portions were decent sized. I liked that they had a variety of noodle soups to choose from. Along with beef pho or chicken pho they have the beef satay noodle soup and bun rieu (crab paste) noodle soups which not all pho places have. All are pretty tasty.

Parking can be a bit tough on the weekend, but I'd come back if in the neighborhood and craving northern pho.
author: Ali F.

description:
The Pho Ga is amazing. The chicken in it is really good, and the Thai tea I usually get with it is delicious.
But the service.. Terrible.
author: Dennis D.

description:
It's been awhile since I last went to Quan Ngon, and the food is still pspretty good.

I tried the Dac Biet beef noodle soup.  Soups has heavy msg taste, no tripes, but the beef is very juicy and soft, unlike the dry thin slices that most pho uses.

Iced coffee is nice and strong, it's not dripped, so when they bring it to the table, it's already in a glass ready to drink.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Raw beef was very yummy. Lots of garlic, onions, cilantro, lime, and fish sauce. 

Chicken pho-not bad at all. Hit the spot. I like!

Cash only.
author: Karen H.

description:
01.01.13

It's new year's day and I'm hungover.  All I want is a big bowl of MSG soup with noodles, and Quan Ngon did not disappoint.

I know they're known for their chicken noodle soup, but their pho tai is not bad!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Definitely not a Vietnamese joint I need to hit up again. I've had it once before and this second time confirmed the mediocrity. Service was weirdly slow even though we were only the second table in the place.

We got the pho ga, the grilled pork over rice, and the five-spice chicken with cha gio on rice noodles. The pho ga didn't have any richness in the broth and the grilled pork was more like little slices of jerky that had been softened. The chicken was decent, but with no char or crunch. Yep, move along since there's nothing to see here.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Do some people mistaken this place for Pho Quan Ngon (shown here on yelp) also on Noriega? Because this place only has 3 reviews so far... including mine 4. This place definitely deserves more review than this!

I came here for #13.. Crab Tomato Noodle Soup. :D O-M-G! Best i've ever had. They give you a side of shrimp paste and jalapenos which perfects the taste.

I came a second time because i was craving for #13 but they were all sold out. :( So i went with the chicken noodle soup. the flat noodle was so soft, you can slurp it right up! Chicken were tender.

Definitely will be back for #13 when I crave noodle soup!
author: Nancy N.

description: Literally worst customer service ever recieved. Would give 0 stars if I could. Literally nothing was in stock. waiting over half an hour for our noodles and the waitress came out to say it would take 20 minutes for the appetizer to come out. The waitress kept on refilling the utensils while we were eating and took away the condiments to refill them. And finally after all this bad service that had the gall to add a 15% tip like we owed them something. Safe to say we're never coming back.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Been here twice now..the first time was with good friends Kelvin and Bush. Kelvin had said that this place had pretty good Chicken Pho, maybe even better than Turtle Tower. So sure enough we had to check it out. That and the fact that it was so close to Bush's place.

Yup the chicken pho was very good, very light, noodles had good consistency and i was very satisfied.

Second time here, was here to have a nice get together with good friends Julie, Adri, and Henry. I then once again ordered the chicken pho. And yes once again I was very satisfied. I can't really compare the chicken pho..but i have to say that there is more chicken here than i had over at Turtle and I like the broth here a bit more too. 

and yes i believe chicken pho is pho ga..
author: phillip w.

description: Arguably the best pho ga in the city(please dont tell the hipsters) and their hot sauce will knock your socks off ( i recommend starting witb one small scoop). Always good, never disappoints.
author: Matt B.

description:
IMPERIAL ROLLS ARE A MUST!

So this place has been here for years and I've lived here even longer, but today was my first time here and came in for lunch.  Had the BBQ pork on vermicelli with egg roll (it really should have said Imperial Roll).  

The roll is crispy, crunchy and it is good and you get two rolls.  That was on top of the meal, followed by the BBQ pork, peanuts, vermicelli, cucumber, bean sprouts and mint along with the sauce.  This dish is a hit.  A bit of stirring around to mix the flavors of the sauce and mint was just right.  I appreciate everything being in one bowl rather than having all the veggies separate.  Everything gets thrown together regardless.

A Go-to-it place in the 'hood.  Enjoy!
author: Stefan L.

description:
Omg! Awesome bun mang vit! Bamboo shoots duck noodle soup! Went here on a day after running by the beach, and was craving pho, however I seen this on the menu and thought I'd try it! Now I dream about it at night! 

The duck is deboned which is awesome, it has a great ginger sauce, and the broth is just light and warm!

Lol 1 dislike is that my sis complains the restaurant smells like old wood or something. But I'll be back!!
author: Nancy T.

description: My boyfriend'fav pho place. #8 is the best. They have decent chicken broth n dark meat.
author: Nga N.

description: One of my favorite Viet restaurants in the sunset. The bun rieu and beef carpaccio are really good here! Usually most places give beef carpaccio as a mountain of slob or very thin slices of meat. However, this place is not stingy with their meat (at least for the beef carpaccio) and the sauce that comes with it is not overpowering. Perfect for the dish.
author: Cheryl P.

description: I like this place - it's small, but their Pho Ga is pretty good! It's almost as good as Turtle Tower. I love this chili sauce they have. Definitely one of my favorite places to go to in this area.
author: Annie H.

description:
AHHHHH after having turtle tower, I really disliked northern style pho.  HOWEVER, after having this place, I AM NOW IN LOOOOOOVE with northern style pho!!!!  This place really has the most tender rare beef that I've EVER had in pho.  The thicker noodles are delicious, and their broth is SOOO good.  

Also, the 5 spiced chicken rice plate is good too!!!!  But def, def, def best pho in SF hands down. AHHHH I WANT SOME NOW.
author: Liz W.

description: This is my friend's favorite place to get chicken noodles. To be honest, food are mediocre and fully loaded with MSG. I felt so thirsty afterwards. There are so many places in the city who can make better Vietnamese noodles. The moment you are done, they will serve you the check and want you out immediately. This place is famous for bad service. Don't expect severs will say thank you. Restroom is a mess. There were no seat covers and paper towel. Remember if you cannot wash your hands properly, this means servers cannot either.
author: J L.

description:
This is legitimately the best Vietnamese food I have ever had. Everything was so fragrant and tasty. I had my usual bun - it had imperial rolls and 5-spice chicken, and lots of vegetables. The sauces were good, if a tiny bit heavy on the fish sauce for my personal preference.

My mom and brother both had the pho with duck, and the pho broth was so amazing I'm pretty sure I ate half a bowl of it all by myself. We also had the butter-fried tofu for the table, and it made an absolute convert out of me. Usually I am not a fan of tofu, but I could have eaten that stuff every day.

Service wasn't overly friendly, but was efficient, fast, and accurate. Really looking forward to coming back and trying out more of the menu!
author: Amanda P.

description:
I usualyl order the chicken pho here which is okay, they give you decent amount of chicken. The noodle is smooth but seems quite soft sometimes. I also tried their rare beef pho here and the soup is okay. It left me really, really thirsty all day. The rare beef on the other hand, is one of the best I had. It was so tender! 

The service is okay. It takes awhile to get the waiter's attention to order, but after that, it's okay.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Summary: food- good pho! Service-horrendous ... Come if you want to be scolded or mistreated.. 

My first time here was horrific. My parents and I came in to have dinner for the first time and the man at the register pointed for us to sit at a table by the restroom, instead we chose to sit at a table beside that one.. As he gave us our menus, we told him the table was a little dirty and he yelled at us saying "then why did you sit here, I told you to sit at the other table".... Seriously? What type of service is that. Tip meter: below 0 now.. 

To add to this, as we ordered our chicken noodle soup, the same man scolded us (with an impatient tone too) about if we wanted a small or a large... SORRY I WAS TAKING MY TIME EXAMINING YOUR MENU. Geez. This is such horrible service. 

To the OWNER: you can serve the most amazing food, but with poor service like this... You won't go far. Re-examine your employees please.
author: Emily L.

description:
Good food, great price.
This is my go-to place for Pho Ga whenever I'm in town. It's a quiet little restaurant and service is quite decent compared to some of the other noodle houses. I'd definitely recommend to those who are craving for a good cheap meal.

They have ran out of their chicken soup base when i went last time.  If that's what you're craving, go a bit earlier.
author: Alan L.

description:
I'm so sorry Guan Ngon, I have to give you 1 star for our experience this evening. I hate to do this to you since I've been eating here for so long when I was living a couple of blocks away and your pho ga had been so fantastic.

I moved out of the Sunset for almost 2 years and I was so missed the taste of the pho ga offering here. Just so happened that my girlfriend was invited to a house party (think poker night w/o food) nearby this evening at 8:30. The girlfriend and I walked in at 7:30pm and thought we would have plenty of time to fill up before she hit the party. Wrong! The house was full. That's a surprise to me because that doesn't happen when I was a regular.

We waited for a few minutes for the (only) waiter to turn over a table for us. Fine, then a couple of tables had finished and left. We got the hot teas and promptly ordered. At this time more customers came in and fill the place up again. I began to notice that more than half of the tables in the dinning hall are sitting without food. Anyhow, we chatted happily and thought all of the customers sitting without food were just came in right before us. Then, 10 minutes gone by, the table next to us got an imperial roll app. Another 10 minutes later, one table got a couple bowls of pho. At 8:00pm, 30 minutes after we're seated, another table of 3 got their order. I'm sorry, did we mistakenly walked into a French joint? where a meal takes over 3 hours? I thought pho supposed to be a quick, worm, and no thrill sort of meal.

I started to suggest to just walk because there were 4 other tables still without food, who arrived before us. A simple math tells us that our food will be here... what?! 8:40pm?! 1) we're staving 2) she'll be late to the party, therefore, we walked. To be fair, the waiter was apologetic when we informed him that we can no longer wait, +1. We're strongly suspecting that there were only 1-2 cooks in the kitchen because clearly informed by the waiter that our order weren't being prepared, after 35 minutes of waiting. 

We ended up walking across the street and ate at ABC cafe. Wonton noodles and deep fried pork chops with noodles in fish broth were both good. But still, we wished we had pho ga instead. At the end of the day, Quan Ngon left us staving and ABC did the job by provided us dinner, in what?! seating to giving the check in 25~minutes. 

Again, I feel so sorry for giving this place 1 star, for how much I love their pho ga a few years back. Too bad that I didn't get a chance to taste it again. I'm sure it's still good or even better, given THAT many people came in this evening. I guess I'll try this place again at some odd hours maybe. C'mon and start focusing on staffing in the kitchen and the dinning hall would you?!  You have done it well before and please bring it back.
author: Rio T.

description: Chicken Pho/ Pho Ga is the way to go here. I prefer this place over Turtle Tower any day. The soup broth is so sweet and flavorful. I also like their chicken salad for starter. They give you so much chicken in the salad, more than any place I have ever been to. The seasoning is perfect, I have no complaint.
author: Linh N.

description: One of the better pho places in the area. I come here usually when i feel like Turtle Tower is too far. I like the soup broth here and their beef is really chewy and soft - that melt in your mouth type of feeling. I usually order the Chicken Pho because i prefer chicken over beef but i always eat some of my bf's - he likes the beef flanks pho. They tend to be super busy at night and it is a small restaurant so i would recommend coming a little earlier than the norm dinner time.
author: Kristina L.

description:
#9 small with beef on the side, please! & extra limes. & a red bean drink. Thank you! You know who this is. :P 

Place is clean, no sticky chop sticks

Switched from southern style lover to only Quan Ngon #9 lover. Aw yeahhh, the beef isn't hard and chewy.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Review is solely based on their beef based pho.

The rice noodle that they use are different and softer than what you may be accustomed to when you think of pho, but it's a GOOD different, not a BAD different. A Vietnamese friend of mine told me that this restaurant's style of pho is more of a Northern Vietnam style, and most restaurants cook southern style? I don't know? Something like that, someone correct me if I'm wrong.

The broth is the same as any other place, good, but nothing to write home about.

But the beef, OMG THE BEEF, WHAT YOU KNOW 'BOUT THAT RARE STEAK ON THE SIDE?!? It is definitely NOT the same type of beef you will get at other restaurants. Soooooo tender it's amazing! Just melts away in your mouth, zomgwtfbbq I drool just thinking about it!!! The same friend told me that this restaurant uses filet minion beef as opposed to the traditional eye round steak. Makes sense, usually other pho restaurants charge an extra $2-3 for a side order of extra steak, I think I paid anywhere from $4-6. TOTALLY. WORTH. IT. 

Whenever I go out for pho, which is quite regularly, I always get the beef broth one with rare steak on the side. It's a comfort food for me so I don't usually judge it harshly and It's one of my all time favorite dishes. Well, this place is now like, my favorite, on crack. 6/5 stars will go again and again and again.
author: Ron T.

description:
Okay food. I only went here two times. I cannot tell it's good or not. The noodle was typical just like other Pho places.  The bathroom could be more clean, I prefer restaurants with clean bathroom. It's right behind one of the tables. The amount of food? Good. I went there hungry and left full stomach. I like their service though. They were friendly, but cash only is only down side for their service.

Cleanness: 3/5
The proportion of the food: 4/5
Taste: 3/5
Service: 4/5
author: Min S.

description:
ordered bun rieu and beef carpaccio.
the bun rieu broth was a bit lacking. not as hearty as most places, but it made do since i was STARVING.
beef carpaccio was good though. sliced thinly and not too much fat.
author: Susy C.

description: I looooove their Pho Ga (#7) I always come here with my boyfriend if either one of us is craving for some chicken noodle soup. It's sooo good here. And the broth tastes better than Turtle Tower on Geary. It's also close by the house, so it's even better. I've tried their Pho Bo Vien before too, it's not that great. Tried their beef carpaccio, the meat was still frozen. So if you ever come here, just order #7 cause it's their specialty =)
author: cadence p.

description:
My partner and I came to this resteraunt by accident. We were checking out the neighborhood and though to give this place a try. 
I must say I was very impressed with the taste of the food. I had the Pho Tai with meatballs. It was hands down the best Pho Tai I have had. Broth was flavorful without having tons of salt or MSG to give it flavor. The rare beef was the most tender meat I have had in a Pho Tai dish. Presentation of the bowl was suprisingly well thought out. 
I read other reviews about their homemade Chili. It lives up to its expectation.. It was HOT! I mean really Hot. But excellent!
My partner had the Chargrilled chicken breast over rice. He was also very pleased. 

Service was great. Even though we originally ordered spring rolls, the got a salad, then got the fried egg rolls. They were quick and attentive. We stuck with the egg rolls. They were also very tasty. 

We are surely planning to come back. This was a great way to start our afternoon since we drove an hour to get to the city.
author: Bruce M.

description: Very surprised at just how good this was - read the reviews and had to take a shot and very, very glad I did - this may just top Turtle Tower...Imperial rolls were nice and crisp, good sized portion and great starter.  Had my typical beef pho with raw beef, beef balls (like the tendon when avail, just not here) - super delicious broth (key of course) and rare beef was excellent - the noodles were nice and thick (my pref) and exceptionally tender and soft - if you like Turtle Tower, this gives TT a run for its money!!
author: Richard D.

description:
This place will forever be known as "Chicken Pho" between my friends and I. Why? Because the only thing we eat here is Number 7 (Chicken Pho / Pho Ga / Whatever you want to call it) If you're feeling cheap or craving for something warm, COME HERE. SIT DOWN. NUMBER 7 LARGE PLEASE. And enjoy. You can thank me later.

Anyways, this is actually comparable to Turtle Tower on Richmond. In fact, I prefer to come here instead since parking is a LOT easier and the wait isn't as bad. As for taste wise, I really can't tell the difference. Especially since I drown the chicken in fish sauce. 

OH, and they play Young and Dangerous soundtrack in the background. What more can you ask for??
author: Eric M.

description:
One of the top pho's I like in SF. I know some may say their food is generic, but for some reason I really liked their pho. The serving was a good size and the price was decent. 

Unlike other pho places, this one used the thin longer noodles. It wasn't bad, but it was different. The soup in general was good and that was all that mattered to me.

The only problem I had with this place was the service. They are similar to King of Thai. Doesn't really ask how the customers are doing, they busy themselves by cleaning or trying to rush the customers. I didn't mind that, it is a pho place. However, they treated my friend rudely. Especially when she asked for soy sauce. They tried to trick her and say the fish sauce was soy sauce. We are both Asian so I found it surprising the guy was trying to trick her. But yeah that was stupid.

Either way good pho, just know the place isn't going to be crazy good on service... then again what do you expect? It's a pho place.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
Best pho place I have found in the sunset thus far. No places compare. This is not the regular thin haired noodles you'r probably use to but they are flat noodless (kind of like chow fun noodles). They dont jip you on noodles or beef! Price is reasonable, seating is usually available but service is average. 

Free street parking is available if you can find it on the surrounding residential streets and also meter parking is available too.

Oh and be sure to order a plate of their beef carpaccio!
author: Tim M.

description:
Chicken noodle soup = chicken pho = nom nom nom.

The price is amazing for what you get in the soup. Just enough chicken, noodles and soup. The soup is a little salty but it's overall, super flavorful and super yummy. Plus, the noodles are like, small flat rice noodles and that makes it even tastier. ^_^ lol

I think I only ever get that here. I think I've gotten their vermicelli once, but I feel like it tastes like other places that make and sell it..

So basically, the highlight of this review is: chicken pho is almost always a win... Just be sure to drink water or tea just in case. 

Cash only!
author: Susan Y.

description: From reading the reviews I understand why some like the service and others don't. I've gotten mixed results. If I play it safe and order my usual, its fine. Not the best I've had but fine.
author: Rich M.

description:
Pho Quan Ngon is a cutely decorated joint that is usually packed with people and serves up Northern-style Pho.  This means, if you like Pho with the thicker, more hearty flat noodles, you might like Pho Quan Ngon.  Unfortunately, we prefer typical Pho noodles so were a lil disappointed with this Pho outting.  The broth was also not to our taste and they didn't bring us the typical plate of herbs, sprouts and lime.  Hmmm... 

Service was ok and the look of the restaurant was nice but we didn't like the Pho.  Even for our experiences with Northern Pho, this was the least appealing.  -3 stars for the bad Pho, 2 stars for the look, cleanliness and service.

Won't see ya there.
author: Susan D.

description: Love the bun rieu here.  And you know it's good because they always sell out!  So make sure you go early, even on the weekdays!
author: Tina L.

description:
The food was ok and the service was horrible.

They messed up my order and wouldn't fix it. When I ask for help the guy wouldn't answer me and walk away. He could obviously hear me because he'd come back 10 minutes later with what I asked for, but the fact that he was being so rude. Theres plenty of other Pho places in the sunset, I highly recommend you find one other than this one.
author: Kilee B.

description: Small, unpretentious restaurant with a wait even at 2pm on a Saturday! Definitely looks like a local favorite. If there is a line, there is a clip board by the door to put your name on. Husband and I each got a small chicken pho ($7.50). Broth flavor was outstanding, with nice thick, flat noodles. Only downside was the portion of chicken was not very generous. Nonetheless, we slurped our bowls up really quickly. And then I passed out at home from the msg. I would still say it was worth it. Parking on Noriega is never fun. When we run out of patience trying to find a spot, we usually can find parking on Ortega and just walk a bit.
author: Lisa H.

description: I ordered the beef carpaccio and was sooooo disappointed. It was so bland and tasted like I was eating nothing! On the other hand I really liked the pho! It was nice and flavorful though I went in craving some BBH only to be let down because they don't have any!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I was never a huge fan of pho until my sister brought me to Quan Ngon and now I come once a week (sometimes more).  Its a different style (Northern style I hear?) with flat rice noodles and they don't give you all the sprouts and mint and other fixin's of most pho places in SF which is fine by me.

I usually go for the combination w/o tendon but the chicken pho and beef satay are delicious too!  The small size will most likely fill you up and its about $6.50-$7 for a bowl which is a good price. 

I docked a star for the service.  The shorter guy that works there is simply inconsistent.  Sometimes he is super attentive and sometimes he is just plain rude.  You would think he'd be a little friendlier considering how frequently we eat there.

It gets crowded around prime meal times, once we were even seated at a 6 person table: 3 different parties of 2! Interesting eating experience... 

Oh and they are cash only! (ATM's are closeby)
author: Siobhan T.

description: The phó here is really good! Especially the chicken! But the service here is HORRIBLE. If it was for how good the food is, I would never come back here. They also don't accept anything but cash as a payment. Definitely have mixed reviews about this place.
author: Josh J.

description:
I am not a Pho fan.. It's always the same thing with the beef soup noodles, so it's more like a fast food joint for me.  However I tried the crab meat with tomato soup before and I really liked it, but there are not many restaurants that serve this.... and I found this place on yelp... so finally we went and #13 !!  It's the best I ever had.  the crab meat balls are actually in a ball shape and not just minced and scattered in the soup like other places.  They also serve it with mint, cilantro,  and shredded cabbage, and shrimp paste!  It's so nice and flavorful!!   I will definitely come back again!!  btw they ran out of #13 when we were paying our bill, so they do run out!!

My dear had the 5 spice chicken and eggroll over rice and the chicken is very tender and soft.  

We also had beef carpaccio and it's great!!

Next time I want to try the duck and the chicken pho that everyone is talking about here!!
author: Jo L.

description:
Pho Tai (rare beef). My Fave. Here is the best one I've had.  They use slightly fatter noodles (like a thin chow fun) which seem to absorb the broth better and essentially make every bite more flavorful.  

They also have chicken pho which is basically like chicken noodle soup.  It's good, but the Pho Tai is my fave by far.
author: Karl D.

description:
Pho ga and bun rieu. Although these are very delicious here, I think it'll be highly unlikely that I ever come back to eat here again. Why? A big part of any good restaurant business is customer service...and this place SUCKS at it. They're so rude, dirty, and have no respect for any of their customers. 

Prior to this review, my family came to dine at this place for lunch at least three times a week. Their food is good and their broth comes out hot which is important for us. However, after hearing about my parents experience when they came here I was furious. During their 2nd visit of the week, the two waiters that was working that day accused my parents for not paying their previous bill. My parents were very confused because they always pay for it and my mom even recalled the last time when they were paying the bill that she asked my dad if they charged for their takeout box before my dad gave his cash and got the change. Although my dad knew it was wrong, he paid for it anyways because he didn't want to start a commotion and genuinely enjoyed supporting a restaurant with good food. But that's stupid on so many levels because those waiters were rude about the situation and probably thought they were able to take advantage of a mistake they may have committed with someone that was sitting next to them that day. If anyone decided to dine and ditch at a restaurant any day... why would they ever go back?! Not only that, but how can you throw a receipt in a customer's face and accuse them? (Cash only, and this might be one of the big problems cause someone could have easily used the money left there to pay for their bill and ditch so that innocents are left to blame.) Besides, even if it was an innocent mistake, you would think the waiters are familiar enough with my parents and they could even let one check go.. considering we feed their business consistently.

They always say the dirtier the place, the better the food. And it's true, next time you eat there be careful that the waiter's dirty fingers are not all up in your soup. He touches all the money, wipes his nose, and doesn't even wash his hands before he brings the food out. 

I would also avoid drinking the hot tea they serve and use it to wash your oily utensils instead. On multiple occasion I've found lipstick stains and tea residue when i wiped the cup down. 

Service is very important, and service here sucks. Less than one star if i could. Be careful and don't let them accuse you of not paying, they think they will catch you. idiots.
author: Johanna T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE WAY MORE THAN TURTLE TOWER AND THIS IS WHY.

the chicken pho here is soooo yummy. i like dark meat (and dark skinned men) so i ask for all dark meat. When im feeling extra meaty i add some meatballs with tendons ($3.50 :[ ) into my chicken pho. Small is just the same size as a large trust me - the large just puts more broth and uses a bigger bowl.

My routine is to put 2 jalapenos, couple of bean sprouts for some texture, and squeeze the shit out of a piece of lime into my broth. Get a sauce pan for their home-ade hot sauce for the chicken, put a dab of it into my soup, and BAM, meal of the year.

I like turtle tower, but its def not as good as this place. The broth here is just so much more tasty and fragrant. Turtle tower, to me, uses broth straight from the can and is pretty bland.

How about you try and compare and tell me what you think!
author: Jennifer T.

description: The Pho Ga is really good but what ruined the experience was the service. The waiter was extremely rude. The minute it hit 9:30 he was closing shop around us and we didn't feel comfortable finishing our pho. Not to mention grabbing our money and throwing down the check. Plain rude it's a shame because the pho was good!
author: Ashley C.

description: NOPE. Tried to order veggie pho and she kept saying chicken was extra. I don't want chicken. After saying I can't eat chicken and turning to walk away she finally got it. Veggie pho. After paying she then casually lets me know it's 20 min. VEGGIE PHO. I wait. I get home to dig in. It's basically noodles in water. NOPE. Off to good noodle to get some actual pho.
author: Kat H.

description: Homemade noodles! Mmmm mmm good!! I do miss bean sprouts, but maybe they don't provide them cause the noodles are so delicate. Fresh spring roll had the perfect balance of everything! Yum!
author: Adventuring P.

description: I prefer take out. I enjoy the rare beef noodle soup and imperial rolls. My boyfriend always gets the beef vermicelli.
author: Brittny R.

description: Number 8, more intestines, less noodles, and a coke please. lol Simple as that. I honestly like this place a lot more than turtle tower... that place is... overrated like tpump.. or whatever u call that place with a long A** LINE 24.7.
author: Annie Y.

description:
DO NOT, I REPEAT DO NOT EAT HERE!

The food is terrible and the place smells like old piss from a public park mixed with lysol spray.   Then the owner/waiter/busboy tried to overcharge us.  I ordered 2 dishes ($6.95 and $7.25) and one thai ice tea ($2.50).  The bill totalled $19.60.  HUH?

I warned ya - BEWARE; IT'S A DISGUSTING PLACE.  You have other options.
author: Poboy U.

description:
Came here on a sunday lunch with the family. This place has the pho that my parents like, which is the chicken pho with intestines and what not. That's not my cup of tea so I ordered the satay beef pho.

This pho place has the different kind of noodles, which are the flat rice noodles. Also it doesn't come with the bean sprouts. My satay beef wasn't that spicy and the soup was a little too thin for me. Just the overall texture for me wasn't that great. I had maybe 5 pieces of meat, and just a bunch of noodles with thin sauce that couldn't really stick to the noodles. 

Parking can be hard since because of all the other grocery stores and restaurants near by. Besides the chicken pho with the intestines, I don't know if you would go.
author: Anita W.

description:
We've been to Vietnam last year and tasted pho-s from various parts of the country, and my favorite was one we ate in Mui Ne. Since then we've tried a lot of pho places in the city, and today we ventured in to Quan Ngon. We had a very good banh xeo (pancake like dish filled with seafood, meat and vegetables) as an appetizer to share and two small pho-s.
