The meat in the beef pho was a little undercooked, my chicken was good. I have been debating wether I should give this place 4 stars, but the pho was just good, not phenomenal, and I'm not a fan of the soft noodle. We also had a Vietnamese coffee at the end, which was just OK.

The service was good, and I don't have anything to complain about, but I'm still looking for that perfect pho spot :-)
author: Timea B.

description:
I come here all. The. Time. 

The fact that I live about 2 blocks from this place might have something to do with it, but the yummy thick noodles and rich beef broth are what compel me to drag my hungover ass out of bed at 3:00 PM on the weekends. 

My only gripe is that this place is cash only and I never, ever carry cash, but BofA is just up the street from here. I only ever get pho here and I've tried their rare beef pho, satay beef pho, chicken pho, chicken with intestines pho.

The chicken pho is pretty good, but I'd definitely say that their beef pho is more flavorful. I usually stick to a large rare beef pho and drown my noodles in Sriracha until they look like their swimming in a pool of blood (appetizing, no??).
author: Jen L.

description: love the chicken noodle soup! haven't tried anything else because it is soo good and I have been here over a handful of times.  Beware do not come for dinner if you are craving the fat noodle because they run out sometimes and offer you the round noodle which is not as good.
author: L E.

description: My egg rolls were bizarrely mealy. Quite unpleasant.
author: Misha T.

description:
ive gotten my good share of pho in the city, but this place is definitely one of my favorite spots. their pho has pretty good broth and the flat and soft noodles was very pleasant to eat. I also really like their chicken salad it has tangy fish sauce, meaty pulled chicken, and crunchy fried shallots topping, all 3 together along with fresh cabbage make a perfect combination. 

their spring rolls are also decent, but i think it has a little bit too much vermicelli in there so whenever i take a bite, i feel like the noodles are exploding out of the roll!

all in all, this place definitely has reasonably priced good food with huge portion and you won't leave here hungry for sure!
author: Joyce C.

description:
This is actually my wife's favorite Vietnamese place in SF.  She goes gaga over the duck noodle soup.  My personal favorite is the curry chicken noodle soup.  Those taters in there are pretty damn good.  I once ordered the large and although i enjoyed it immensely, it hurt so good for a couple of hours after because I ate too damn much!  From now on, its always the small bowl for me.

What I like about this place is they even have the 'white person' option of requesting 'no bones' !!!  That's pretty awesome.  As a white dude, I lack the oral gymnastics necessary to navigate edible portions from random bone pieces that are the default option in the chicken curry dishes.  You gotta learn those skills growing up Asian I suppose.  What's also funny is they give the white people forks with their rice noodle dishes. Nice.

The rice noodle dishes are also good.  I like the five spice chicken one with rolls.  If you're into pork, the BBQ rice noodles are a good choice too.
author: barry a.

description: Fast service and really good pho.  That's all that I really go here for though.  Cash only is the downside.
author: Jon I.

description:
They placed a large bowl of pho with rare and well done beef in front of me before I even ordered :-).  That's fast service!  What they put in front of me smelled and looked so good.  I explained the mistake but they let me keep the pho.  The large bowl is huge...I couldn't finish it even though it tasted so good.

I didn't miss the bean sprouts at all.  I found the Northern style pho more comforting w/o the sprouts.  You barely have to chew at all.  The flat rice noodles (which I really like) glide into your mouth without much effort.  The rare beef and well done beef both were delicious and the well done beef wasn't tough.  

I usually like the basil, but I was happy with the cilantro in the soup and I didn't miss it that much either.

I can see why some people think the broth is lacking in something - it isn't as complex as some pho broth I've had (is this because it is Northern style?).  The broth is lighter and still quite good.  More importantly, they serve it piping hot and the usual sauces are provided.  With the sauce, lime juice and jalapenos, the broth is very nice.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Good north viet pho
Dirty cheap quick noodle joint
Bad rice dishes tho

Yelp haiku! Yay!
author: Aron L.

description: I've had the pho tai and the pho ga. Like Turtle Tower, they use a slightly wider noodle and don't serve basil/bean sprouts on the side. The pricing is also in line with Turtle Tower's, so it is more expensive than many pho places, but the serving size is pretty generous. The beef broth was good if not a little salty, and there was probably some MSG because I was a little thirsty afterwards. The chicken broth was a little more subtle. Overall, I liked the pho ga at Turtle Tower better because their broth seems more fragrant, and I liked the pho tai here better. Service was rather slow, and we had to ask for water twice before we got it. I do like the noodles and the broth in this style of pho, though. It is a little different from the usual places that use the thinner, dried noodles and give herbs and bean sprouts on the side. Parking in this stretch of Noriega is usually not too bad. A bowl of pho here would definitely hit the spot on a cold day in the Sunset.
author: Alex Y.

description:
A hidden gem for pho in the city!

I came here for a late night dinner with some friends. The friend who took us here said she came to this place often and sometimes preferred it over Turtle Tower (a popular pho spot). We all ordered the Pho Tai with meat on the side. It definitely hit the spot.

I'm no pho expert but I am aware that there is a Northern and Southern version to this popular Vietnamese dish. The noodles served here are northern style pho, which means they're wider. Not vermicelli-like. The broth was delicious and definitely competes with Turtle Tower's.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I had the Sliced Beef & Meatball Pho.  The broth was just salty, but not anise-y.  The amount of meat was negligible.  The side dishes were only lime and sliced jalapenos.  

The bathroom, which opened directly into the dining room, was disgustingly filthy, and it was only noon on a Sunday.

I would NOT recommend this place.
author: Robyn C.

description: Been here multiple times and their pho ga never ceases to amaze me!! (: first time here, I had pho curry ga & craved it the next few days! I swear, it's like there's crack inside! Then I had their pho ga & I fell in love again! I think this is the best pho ga place in the city... But try to prove me wrong if you can!
author: Carin S.

description:
This is my new favorite pho place in SF. Having traveled all over vietnam last year and eaten some of the best pho ever, this place is pretty close to authentic hanoi style pho I've had in SF.

Hanoi style pho is just the soup, noodles, meat, but none of the sprouts, basil and extras they give you on the side.

The soup base is really good, and not overly salty or msg laden. The special part are their really thin and soft white noodles-not the ordinary chewy, hard pho noodles you get everywhere else that end up tasting  like plastic as it absorbs the liquid in the bowl as you eat it. 

Cilantro, green onion is in the bowl already, so all you add is lime, and jalopeno slices and wala! Vietnamese comfort in a bowl!

i can say this is the only pho place where i've actually finished a entire bowl of pho noodles, all the way down to the last piece of noodle/beef- yes its good!

And reasonably priced at $6.95 for a small and a few bucks more for a large (although I think large has same ingrediants as small but just more broth).

VIetnamese ice coffee is good and strong, but not 100% like vietnam but will do.

Service is good and fast, and everytime Ive gone its always a packed house no matter what hour it is, but turnover is fast!

They also have oxtail pho on their menu- something i want to try next time.
author: Petri Y.

description:
OMG do not eat here. First of all, my boyfriend and I are veterans when it comes to PHO. We have out usual favorite places but decided to come here on a Sunday night for dinner. I thought in my mind, "How can you really mess up PHO?" Apparently this place can. 

Boyfriend ordered the number 12 which is beef and beef ball Pho. The BEEF BALL was as my BF described"eating a DEAD TOE with a bone in the middle." It had a foul smell and taste. He tried to give one more a try and again it was the DEAD TOE syndrome. 

I ordered a veggie Pho, and it came out smelling like bamboo shoots, which is fine but it was really really strong. There were tomatoes in my Pho which was weird so I picked them out. As I was eating my Pho I felt a texture in my mouth very similar to plastic. As I spit it out, what do you know, it was a piece of PLASTIC. I fished around in my soup and there were large strands of plastic. 

BF and I quickly signaled the waiter and he came and apologized. He took the Pho off the check but our bill was still $16 bucks since we ordered Imperial Rolls and the BF DEAD TOE SOUP. I found that expensive. I guess we are just spoiled and used to having inexpensive good PHO. 

Don't go here.
author: Mar M.

description: This place sucked!! People here are so rude like they do not care for your business.  The guy at the front (owner?) has no business working there. We were not done with ordering our food and he just walk away being annoyed. What the hell!! We are paying for your existence. If you are so pissed working there, go home. No one wants to see your sour face or just go bury yourself. Hope Turtle Tower opens next to this place and kill it.
author: Stephanie C.

description: They are known for their Chicken Pho! (Pho Ga) and it's alright! The place is small and cozy and its very close by to my school. Theres a lot of parking out on the street or the neighborhoods. NOT BAD :)
author: Sandy C.

description:
quan ngon, i love your pho ga (chicken pho), #7! i can't go a week without visiting this place because it's honestly the perfect noodle-soup for any cold and foggy day in the sunset (which is almost everyday!)

the broth is flavorful, the chicken is tender and delicious, and the fat-rice-noodles are my favorite! For $6.50 + tax for a small, some people may think it's more expensive than other pho restaurants but trust me!, you get what you pay for! the chicken and beef taste tender and the broth isn't drowned in msg! A small bowl here is equivalent to a medium at other pho-joints but the large is definitely worth the extra dollar if you're hungry or eat a lot. 

I've also tried their beef noodle soup ( +/- beefballs) and their bun rieu! I prefer the beef-noodle soup here waaaaaay more than those offered on irving, so even if you're not craving chicken noodle soup, there are other delicious options available!

yeah, the service can be slow when they get busy but the food comes out pretty quickly! 

quan ngon, i will see you soon!
author: Patricia K.

description: This place is alright. I've came here probably about 4-5 times and I would always order the beef pho. They use the thick noodles instead of the thin ones and I usually like the thin ones. The broth is pretty good and the food comes out quick. I tried the pho ga this time because it seems like everyone likes it here but I didn't really like it. I definitely like turtle tower better because their broth is more flavorful and their chicken and intestines don't taste old. As I was eating the chicken and intestines, it tasted old to me and I was hoping that I don't get sick from eating it. In terms of service, I've always received quick and friendly service from the waiter. He would say hi and say thank you but today was the first time where I SEE the bad customer service that everyone is talking about. When I arrived, we were seated quickly by the waiter and we didn't know that the tables were not cleaned. When we just sat down, the waitress cleaned the table AND my sweater. Like how do you even miss the table... Clearly she has no self control over her own body. She then threw the menu on the table and then she said sorry. At least she said sorry but I don't appreciate that dirty rag touching my sweater. The food came out pretty fast and we got what we asked for. We asked for the bill and paid. The waitress was cleaning tables right in the front of the restaurant and I was expecting a thank you in Cantonese but nope.. Nothing. I understand that it's a Chinese establishment and that their service won't be up to par but I do know that they know how and when to say thank you. I think you should only come during the weekdays where it's slow and only the waiter is working. He does have a sense of customer service and makes sure to say thank you when you leave.
author: Brenda K.

description: First off, I eat here A LOT. It isn't fancy by any means, just a quick place to eat lunch or dinner. Honestly, the service here is pretty bad (-2 stars). They often forget to bring by waters and other things I ask for like extra napkins, you can sometimes catch the waiter with his finger dipped in the soup (which he also handles money with), and there is definitely sometimes a language barrier. Forgetting about the service and sticky tables, I still like this place because the pho is too good to pass up. I always get the chicken pho, but I also like the beef pho. It's northern style so the noodles are thicker, flatter, and chewier than the more popular pho noodle style. The beef in the beef pho is super tender, but they don't give you much of it. I have also gotten the raw beef appetizer which was good...but hard on the stomach, so I'd pass on that. Their ox tail stew is also really good! Flavorful and comes with plenty of warm french bread. Basically, if you can turn a blind eye to everything but the food, it's a solid spot.
author: Natasha H.

description: I'm a fair guy - I'm revising my review. Don't remember why my original review was so bad, but I've been here several times in the last couple years and it's been good.
author: Edward S.

description: They ran out of bon rieu the one time I came here and I was super craving it. I was very sad, so I ended up just getting the usual beef combo. This place does it northern styled, just the way I like it. The service was good and fast. It's a pet peeve of mine when restaurants overgive that and having to throwing it away when people can't put it all in their bowl. But that's not a problem here! Anyways, I'm definitely coming back for the bon rieu next time and maybe even the pho ga, though I'm always wary of trying the chicken at places that don't exclusively specialize it. And of course, CA$H ONLY.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Their pho ga was just ok.  I found their broth lacking. Maybe b/c I am used to having Turtle Tower?? Anyway, came in another time and ordered their spring rolls.  That was not good at all.  I think I will just stick w/ their pho ga next time.

Pros are that it's never that busy and short wait if you want pho in the sunset.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Very good Chicken Pho as opposed to the traditional Beef noodle soup.

This place is definately better than the one on Geary ave.

The chicken broth is rich and noodles are smooth. 

I would stay away from beef noodle soup here but definately order PHO GA (chicken pho) everytime.
author: Lawrence Y.

description: I usually order the chicken noodle soup here when I come since that's the only order I know for sure that's good. But the last time I came I ordered Bun Rieu! It was so flavorful and they were generous with the amount of crab meat/tomato. I'd skip out on the drinks though, they're ok.
author: Melissa C.

description:
My boyfriend likes this place and the egg rolls were good. Now onto the review...

I can not stress enough the reason for wearing gloves. It is NOT so that your hands won't get dirty from touching food, its so the food won't get dirty touching your hands! Me seeing you wearing gloves outside the kitchen does not make me think you're giving me clean food. 

They need new menus, theirs were old and crusty. They need to deep clean the walls, all the way up to the ceiling, I could see food/soup splashes on the wall I was next to, and dried condensation that had dripped down. Lastly, they need to not serve customers dried out chicken. Yes, I'm white, but I live in sf, I know good asian food. 

All in all, I didn't finish my meal and won't be back.
author: A. H.

description:
I think I like this place more than Turtle Tower! =X 

My new favorite place for Northern Vietnamese pho!! I still love Southern Vietnamese pho, but I'm liking Northern style a bit more, because they use chicken. I always order #8 which is the pho with chicken, and chicken intestines! You can order your chicken, with no skin, and all white meat too. 

This place usually gets a little busy during the afternoon, but isn't as busy during the evening. Oh, and it's cash only! There is plenty of parking, meter parking, and if you circle around the blocks you can find parking without meters. The people who work here are always nice, they have always thanked us before we left or while we're walking out the door. This is my first 5 star rating in a long time, it has to mean something then, right! =)
author: Heather C.

description: Perfect for a cold weather day.. the chicken broth is so good,  i added rare beef in my noodle,  taste like a personal hot pot.  I love this place.  This is the only vietnamese noodle place in SF  that does NOT give me a dry mouth because of the msg.  Gooood....
author: Toshiko B.

description:
do you remember the meal that saved you from the dead?
yes, the one after you had the WORST HANGOVER of your LIFE!


mine was at Quan Ngon!
thin flat wide noodles
soft pieces of meat, definitely not ribeye.. something cheaper and pounded into submission like my nightcap on Friday night


unorthodox pho, the  freshest taste not too salty... you can taste the quality, real authentic broth nothing from the package.

no basil different but it was d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s...
author: Braden K.

description: The food is good i had #9 large and a three color bean drink... i can confirm the service was alittle slow even though there were only 3 tables total including us..But i'll gice them a second shot soon the beef in the pho was tender and the broth tasted good, but i'm not use to the thicker noodles..lolz
author: jonathan h.

description: I've been here before and don't remember it being this bad. Ordered Pho with raw beef and imperial rolls. The rolls were OK, nicely fried, came with one lettuce leaf and vermicelli. The beef pho soup had a ton of MSG. About half way through the bowl my tongue started to go numb. I stopped eating it and have spent the entire afternoon drinking green tea and water and I'm still dying of thirst!
author: K M.

description:
This place is suppose to be good for their Pho Ga??  ummm...no way!!  Their broth is not what I am accustomed to in Pho Ga's...

The only reason I gave them 3 stars is due to their Bo Tai Chahn!  One of thee best in SF!!
author: Patrick C.

description: Recommend the five-spice chicken over rice, The Bun Bo Hue was not very good, they don't have enough of the spice flavor. Overall, fast and good service.
author: Lily L.

description: This place definitely improved the past year or two. It's my go-to place to cure my hangovers. With Turtle Tower jacking up their prices, this is a great alternative (and right in my neighborhood too, SCORE!). The Bun Rieu here is the best I've had in a restaurant in San Francisco. It comes real close to my ma's. They do not have pork blood though if you're into that. The hot sauce is pretty good too, I think they might make it themselves, not sure though. Don't quote me on that.
author: Anita W.

description:
Not terrible for pho, but definitely not worth going to again with all of the other Pho spots in the Sunset and Richmond. 

I dined here with my dad and sister for a quick bite to eat.  And as with most Pho joints, service in terms of getting food out in a timely manner was quick.  

Dad and I both ordered Beef Combination Pho-Large, for around 7 bucks.  I'm not a fan of the thicker Northern pho noodles that this spot only serves up.  And I would've liked to have the option for the thinner pho as well.  But hungry as I was, I ate.  The little sis ordered the 5 Spiced Chicken over Rice.

Even though service was efficent and quick, I was disapointed as they failed to provide us with mint leaves and bean sprouts for our broth.  This has never happened to me before in a Vietnamese restaurant.  

Broth was alright after I drenched it with Chilli sauce and Hoisin sauce.  Normally a little squirt of each to add a little zing does the trick, but this particular time I had to continuously add more sauces and lime to enhance the flavor.  

The beef was extremely tough to where you would be chewing it thousands of times and it wouldn't get any softer.  Furthermore, the beef balls were huge...literally 2 and a half inches in diameter.  I'm used to those 1 inch bite sized beef balls.  The beef balls also had really hard rubbery texture.  

The 5 Spiced Chicken was actually pretty good. White meat was juicy, and the plate was complimented with a nice side portion of pickled cabbage, raddish, and carrots.  

The restaurant itself is small, with only about 10 tables or so.  The clean and always nicely bussed tables is a plus.  

Overall, I don't think I will be coming back here for Pho, as we came here for convenience--quick and convenient it was.  Other than that, this spots lacks in terms of the noodles.
author: Cass J.

description: Awesome food, awesome service.  We're always seated immediately and the food comes out quickly.  There are also vegetarian options (and vegetarian broth).  Cash only.
author: Lorelei C.

description:
When this place opened, I came here at least once a week. WhY? Not sure. Definitely one of the better Pho Ga places, which the thicker rice noodles instead of the pho noodles. It's about as clean as your neighborhood Vietnamese restaurant can get but that's not saying much... but service is quick and they get the job done. 

Like for real I used to think this place was totally awesome. Maybe I am over it or maybe its not as good as it used to be. But its still not bad!! Although the last time I ate here, I left very thirsty, which is sometimes an indication of too much MSG. oh well... wouldn't be good if it wasn't!

The imperial rolls/egg rolls are just ok, not really Vietnamese style but more Chinese style (which the skin that they use).

I have never eaten anything here but the Pho Ga. My friend had the beef ball pho once and said it wasnt good... but thats not their specialty!
author: Bobbie L.

description:
This is the Sunset's version of Turtle Tower...

-I really enjoy the Pho Ga here. The broth is very clean and pure...just the way I like it. 

-The servers here work slow and look very pompous. I don't get a good vibe from them at all. I usually have to ask twice for things...and they are never apologetic for anything. 

-Can get pretty busy during lunchtime...you'll probably have to share a table or wait a little while. 

I definitely recommend coming here for the food...they got a nice selection of great tasting dishes here. It's great when you need something good, quick and cheap....but don't expect anything from the service here.
author: Allan M.

description:
Really good tasting broth and very tender beef. Not use to the wider noodles but they were pretty good 

The imperial rolls were really tasty. They were made when the order was placed so they were nice and crisp. We will be back
author: Jennifer S.

description: This is my all time favorite restaurant! They have the best pho noodles ever! The waiter usually knows what I want every time I sit down cause I usually always get the same thing  #13 large with the beef on the side. Yum yum yum yum!!!!!! The pork egg roll appetizer is good too and cant forget the spring rolls!
author: Lydia L.

description:
I agree 100% with Minkz N.  People should understand that this is a Northern Vietnamese restaurant, not Southern.  They do not serve bean sprouts and mints here with their noodles.  The typical way to eat these dishes is with lime and chili only.    

Have you ever been to Turtle Tower or the recently-opened PPQ Chicken Noodle House?  This place is WAY better than both of them.  The dishes are good-sized and soup has no MSG.  The flat noodles are soft, smooth and perfect.   The Duck/Bamboo noodle dish ROCKS! The duck is de-boned and comes with an authentic ginger sauce that is delicious.  This is one of the best NORTHERN Vietnamese noodle soup house out there!!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Definitely not too amazing; some dishes are rather greasy, killer loaded with MSG, and the whole menu lacks vegetarian options, as only one dish was somewhat meat free (tomato crab dish.) They have a decent Northern Vietnamese restaurant going on with their Pho Ga and smooth, flat rice noodles, but their lack of service is killing it for them.

Food comes out FAST; almost two minutes the last time I went! Might have been cooking on the stove since that morning, who knows...

Anyways it's really not my favorite place to eat, but hey, it's local and not too expensive. Cheap eats, here you are.
author: Colleen M.

description:
This place is alright. I had the pho, it was nothing too special, but they do have huge beef balls. 

The menu is small and simple.

Negative:
My friends and I saw the employee using a dollar bill to put pepper into the pepper shaker. There's a better and more sanitizing way of doing that!
author: Mandy D.

description:
Best Pho In The Bay!

THEY. HAVE. CHICKEN.
THEY. HAVE. DUCK.

It's totally different with the taste here. They give you a large amount of noodles and beef! I don't feel my mouth being dehydrated after eating so much MSG. I feel liek this place doesn't even have MSG! LOVE IT. The service is great, too! It's usually one person handling the floor and they're usually fast. 

Great place. Definitely recommended for Pho lovers in the area and don't want to go to Irving or Westlake. :)
author: Iris L.

description:
Oh Noriega, I do appreciate all the delicious asian cuisine within walking distance from my home.

I always went to the other Pho' place down the street from here. After walking by this place all the time and seeing it always had human traffic. I figured I've give it a shot, since I'm a true pho' fanatic.

I ordered the Combo Beef Pho', my girlie got the 5 spice chicken combo. When I tasted the broth, I knew right away I was coming back. It was simply delicious. My gf finished most of her meal too. She's very picky when it comes to Vietnamese food. 

Gladly I found a pho place that I can just throw on some clothes on a random morning/afternoon to trot right over to please the pho belly craving. =)
author: Tip S.

description:
This place looks like a dive, which seems to scare off a lot of people.  

Good.  More pho for me!

The prices are pretty darn cheap, proportions large, and the food is good.  The broth's simple, noodles are the wide type, and the Vietnamese carpaccio is delicious!
author: Sam W.

description:
I live pretty close to PQN and have been here a few times for the Pho Ga. 
You can really distinguish the difference in aroma and flavors of the northern pho ga compared to the southern Vietnamese pho's. 

The noodles are also a bit thicker compared to southern pho and personally, have a much better texture. You can slurp it up much easier!! 

The pho broth is much more acidic but the last few times i have had it was too lukewarm for my taste...

i love my soup hot hot hot, just how i like my women.. heh
author: Jason W.

description:
The chicken pho here used to be very good, piping hot broth and good noodles with just the right amount of chicken pieces. When they first started they pretty much only had the chicken pho, but gradually they added more and more dishes including beef pho, and rice dishes. I've tried most other dishes and I have to say that it is average at best. Pretty much the best thing on the menu is the chicken pho. However last couple of times I've been there, it just wasn't hot enough for me. I mean it is still tasty but it has lost a little of its charm for me. That plus 
I don't think it is that cheap to eat here. Was just here tonight and I ordered a large chicken pho, small bun rieu (tomato crab broth noodle), an imperial roll, a shrimp roll and two drinks. Bill with tip was around $40. Is that cheap to you? I just don't know, I mean I can pretty much get the same in terms of quality of food at a chinese restaurant for $30. Maybe it's like comparing apples and oranges but paying $40 for a couple bowl of noodles just seems out of whack. 

Mainly because it is so close to my house, I'll be back but the frequency is getting less and less.
author: Dom L.

description:
Boo.. this place ain't no Quan Ngon (translates to Delicious Restaurant)!!  Too bad Turtle Tower was closed.  I was craving some North Pho, so my girlfriend and I trekked across the park to this place.  It was quite disappointing.  Maybe it was cause we've been spoiled with Turtle all these years.  

We ordered 1 beef and 1 chicken.  The chicken wasn't tender at all.  The soup wasn't hot (how I like it).  It felt like it had been sitting around all day.  They didn't have tendon with balls (only balls) so we settled with the beef combo.  The whole meal just wasn't that good.  The flavor lacked and the preparation was just average at best.  I would want to go back to this place so maybe they could prove me wrong, but I wouldn't recommend it.  

*nom nom*
author: Steve H.

description:
Big noodles. Not enough of the basil & lime & such that I love to put in. And the employees shouted on the phone the whole time and took the big ol' garbage can out the front door, right in front of me, kinda gross. Doesn't one wait till closing time to do that?

The pho itself was pretty tasty though, but I prefer the thinner noodles.
author: Dina G.

description: They have BUN MANG VIT. Do you know how hard that is to find? And the sauce they give to pour on top of the duck + cabbage is so tasty and perfectly compliments the veggies. However, I tried ordering the Pho Bo once and must say, I won't do so again. It's wasn't as good as I expected it to be given that I enjoy their other items more. But don't let that deter you cuz it sure doesn't stop me from coming back.
author: Julie L.

description: I think the reviews here pretty much nailed it.  The food is not bad at all but the service is beyond horrible.  From all the time I've been there, only the young lady is very nice and sweet.  The most horrible service I got was actually from the man, not the older lady that lot of the yelpers mention.  The man is very nasty, mean and give tremendous attitude for simple things you ask of him.  I have found myself another PHO place close to my work and I have to say those server are so nice I wondered why I even tolerated such bad service before from this place. Needless to say, I don't come to this place anymore.  I also frequent Kevin noodle house as well and those people there are also much more decent, at least they don't curse you out for asking extra accessories.  Service for me is more important than the food and I don't ask for much either.  I don't require smiles and thanks but please don't give me nasty looks and snickers when I order or ask for some extra condiments.  These guys need to know there are so many restaurants out there that you are so replaceable.  Oh yeah, and I forgot to mention, I found some dead small flies (you know, the very small ones) on my Pho noodle dish but I didn't bring it up to them and it won't matter anyways since I won't come here anymore.  For me, I am one business you will loose forever and I feel so much more relax now that I'm in the new PHO place served by pleasant nice people.
author: Hairy Potmaker C.

description:
one word:

RUDE

T___T so mean on the phone mang.

and the pho aint even all that. HMPH
author: Christine M.

description:
Updating again...

This place is now my Go-To for pho. I love the northern noodle style, it's my obsession! They bring me exactly everything I need and nothing I don't! The broth is pure and simple, love it!

I still think the spring rolls are whack, but I avoid them and get the number 10 with my rare steak on the side, extra lime! TYVM!
author: MrsKimch I.

description:
highlights:
* best (or only?) northern vietnamese style pho in the sunset hands down
* decent prices $6.95 for a bowl of pho
* good service, attentive and friendly staff

fav's:
old favorite: #9 Small Pho Tai (rare beef) $6.95
new favorite beverage: red bean ice drink $2.95?
new favorite appetizer: fried butter tofu w/ spices $5.75

note:
i've been coming here for years and do not plan on stopping any time soon :)

neighborhood:
watch out for DPT parking agents! make sure your parking meter is paid for, or else..
author: Brian C.

description:
By far, I would say this IS my favorite pho place. Because it is special.

Now this is not your typical pho noodle style. It's the Northern Vietnamese style noodle. Which they use flat rice noodles, a little bit wider and much softer than the typical vermicelli. 

Why is this place so awesome? first of all GREAT BEEEEEEF. I have not eaten a more tender raw beef & well done beef than this place. No where. Usually other places, the well done beef is very tough and rough, and the raw beef is a little bit more tender, but still rough when it stays in the broth for too long.

They're very generous on the greens, cilantro, scallions, onion, which I love. Totally brings out the flavors.

Beef broth is EXCELLENT, plenty of beef flavor to go around.
This is the only few pho places nowadays that gives big enough portion (compared to other large bowls) to feed me.
author: Theo T.

description: If I still lived in the set, I'd be here once a week. This pho is like crack. People talk about how good turtle tower is, but I think that spots overrated compared to here. Gotta get the bowl with all the goodies. Chicken pho is a must. I haven't tried anything else and don't need to. This place is a done deal.
author: Brian C.

description:
Pho Quan Ngon is like my family's second kitchen.  It's our default restaurant on days where we want a quick bite or if we're just too lazy to cook.  I usually get the chicken noodle soup, which comes with flat and wide rice noodles, which is a little different from your traditional pho noodles because it is northern style pho.  

I've also had the tomato and crab pho, satay beef pho, chicken curry, beef noodle soup, and duck and bamboo pho.  Everything I've ordered here has been decent and for a vietnamese restaurant, they have pretty good service.

I usually take my white friends here to try pho because it's cleaner and less ghetto than most pho places.  This place is also great for ordering to go.  They are quick and they pack up the pho in different containers for the soup, noodles, and garnish, which makes everything easy to transport and to eat
author: Maggie L.

description: I honestly don't think this place is that bad compared to the other reviews that I have read. The waitress suggested that I try the beef satay noodles, which had some spiciness in it. The beef was quite rare (which I like) and tender and I loved the thicker cut noodles (as opposed to the really thin kind that I'm used to). This place is also very clean for a pho restaurant. The downside would definitely be the service. The lady rushed us to order quickly and then when the check came, grabbed the check after 10 seconds without even giving us a chance to pay. What's with trying to get rid of your customers so quickly? I looked around and the restaurant was pretty empty, except for two or three other tables. Other than that, I like my first taste of North Vietnamese style pho noodle soup!
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Chicken pho has never failed in soothing my hang overs.

 Yes, yes .. we've all had the "I'm never drinking ever again" mornings so trust me .. chicken pho is your cure. Tasty, warm, rich broth .. what more could someone dehydrated ask for? Additionally, it's cheap so you can afford it after dropping  big bucks for last night.
author: Brenda C.

description: Was told the pho ga was as good as TT. I would disagrees with them. TT is still better but this place is food also. The soup base is different bit at least I can still stay on the sunset for good pho ga!
author: King L.

description:
This place is not great but my boyfriend loves their Pho Ga. It's a Vietnamese place but one speaks Vietnamese. *so offended* It's crowded but everyone is Chinese. This place locates in the outer sunset area. I'm not surprised their customers are mostly Chinese.

Their Pho Ga tastes like Chicken Noodle Soup. There's no bean sprouts serve. I asked for it, they denied me. Their Bun Rieu did not taste great either. Imperial Rolls were great, but if a place uses menlo wrap for their roll, then it's not authentic. 

I have to be critical because I know how my heritage food should taste like. I'd recommend two doors down "Tay Giang" that place serves real Vietnamese food!
author: MT D.

description:
i love this place. I usually order number 35...i don't remember what the name of it is but it  has cold rice noodles, bean sprout, mint, cucumbers, carrots, hot BBQ pork and fried egg rolls. It is so refreshing to eat.
The service is fast and the environment is nice too.
author: Vespa Fox C.

description:
This place tries to capitalize on the success that Turtle Tower has with their pho ga. While it's decent, it doesn't compare to the original. I come here when I am having a craving for pho ga but don't want to venture out into the Tenderloin or the Richmond district. 

Their bun rieu however, is very tasty. It has just the right amount of tang from tomato and they give you quite a bit of the meatballs.
author: Derrick L.

description:
--This review reflects only the basic pho bowl.--
I only recently started eating pho. Living in the Sunset gives you quite a few places to choose from when you're seeking Vietnamese cuisine. A coworker recommended this place to me after I mentioned I didn't know where to start. I only ordered one of their basic pho bowls, regular size, so I don't have an opinion on anything else they serve. The pho was pretty good, and the amount was certainly filling. I do like however, when restaurants provide you with all the garnishes on the side (cilantro, onion, chili, bean sprouts), which this restaurant does not do, at least by default. 
All-in-all, solid pho, not the best I've had, but good. I would consider coming back here, though first I want to try some other places.
author: Alex V.

description: How can I live in the neighborhood for 5 years and JUST discover this place?  OMG.  Best chicken pho ever.  Now, I don't have to leave the Outer Sunset again -- for pho, that is.
author: K W.

description:
I'll be honest, i'm a little biased. I like Southern style a lot more then Northern, but i'll still eat it once in a while.

When i try a new pho place, i usually try pho ga (chicken pho). I felt like this place didn't taste good at all. My boyfriend didn't like his pho either. Turtle Tower tasted better than here.

However, my friend and her boyfriend seem to really like this place. The 5 spice chicken looked good.

The tea was a little weird, and didn't come out hot.
author: Jennifer Q.

description:
One of the things I love about eating pho is the whole pho experience.

The aroma of the soup as it comes out, steaming hot.

The bowl of aromatics.

A pot of hot tea.

My lunch here included the pho but not the experience.  The soup was ok.  There were no aromatics save a bowl of jalepenos.  The noodles were fresh but not traditional pho noodles.  The hip hop in the background was jarring as I sipped my glass of hot water.

it was not awful.  Kind of left me with the feeling that I had just had fast food, but at the price of a restaurant meal.

I'll stick with Tay Giang on this side of town.
author: Liz S.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of this place. The pork rolls (appetizer) were delicious.

This place is Northern style Thai, which means no sprouts, basil, and no round noodles. Not a huge deal, but sometimes I miss the aforementioned.

Their noodles are flat but still delicious. The #35 Pho Ga (chicken noodle) is pretty tasty with delicious broth. A small is pretty damn big.

A friend got the fatty duck; she said she enjoyed that as well.

I'll be back for more.
author: Jamie M.

description: Meh. I don't like northern style pho. Jess S. wanted some chicken pho so I accompanied her. The pho was okay, but keep in mind that I don't like pho ga. The chicken salad, on the other hand, was quite delicious. This is a one man show though. Don't expect any smiles from the owner/waiter/cashier.
author: Audrey T.

description:
Quick. Cheap. Tasty. Parking. That's probably what Pho Quan Ngon means in Vietnamese. And if it wasn't, no one would know. These guys are not Vietnamese, and I am not complaining.

I actually have a good way to figure out if you'd like this place. If you are Vietnamese, this is probably not for you. Perfect for anyone else.

Pro tip: You can get the five spices chicken on the side with Pho for about a buck more.
author: Joe Z.

description:
Came here to try their northern style chicken noodle soup (and my sister had informed me that theirs was the best... as well as other yelp reviews).

The tea served came out piping hot and we were all glad for it too because it was so cold! We ordered the imperial rolls which also came with some vermicelli (yay!). And very soon after, the phos came out. 

I put some jalepenos and some lime juice in my pho.. let it simmer.. and then I dug in. And I thought it was pretty good. I really liked the small, flat rice noodles that were in the pho - reminds me of my mom's cooking. As for the broth, I think it could have been a little more sweet and/or savory. But I'm a picky eater and am really only familiar with southern style pho. My mom, sister and sister's bf devoured their bowls. 

Good place to go when it's chilly and you need some chicken soup!
author: Christine C.

description:
After all I've heard about Hanoi-style pho, I was so sure I would dislike it.  But my regular place on Noriega was closed.  Today that was allright though because otherwise I would have never discovered that Quan Ngon's pho tai ROCKS.  I've come here for imperial rolls before but never had the balls to try the infamous wide noodles sans bean sprouts and, gasp!, served straight up with no basil -- only lime and jalapeno.  

Of course I had to customize it (read: Saigon-ify it) for my palate.  Here is what to do: come in a group of two or more and convince somebody in your party to order the crab and tomato soup, because not only is it a deliciously different treat, the finely shredded raw cabbage that comes with it makes an excellent substitute for the missing bean sprouts in your pho!  I am sure there are people who will hate me for doing this.  Even the waiter advised me against it.  It's just that I really need the extra fiber, excuse. (TMI!)

Anyway I think I like the beef broth here more than anywhere else in SF, it's definitely in my top four or five beef broths ever.  The other major draw would be the fresh, tender cuts of beef, with a nicely aged quality that nipped my PMS (beef, I need BEEF) hunger right in the bud.  Surprising even myself, I finished almost all of those thick-cut northern noodles, which were super fresh and chewy.  

I love this spot... I am thinking it is the outer Sunset's equivalent to Turtle Tower, only with better music?

[5 Marxist hot cocks]
author: Molasses C.

description:
Pho. Comfort food. I have the stuff ALL the time. It's an instant upper for me. It has the mystical powers to do many things (warm you up on a cold day, cure a hangover, make you feel better when you're feeling poopy) I love it. In fact, I hate it when I meet someone who says they don't like pho, let alone soup. It's like they have no soul! 

I love it but I've never reviewed any of the pho places I frequent. I'm compelled after eating here. Why? The atmosphere is different from your standard pho joint. Sans the flourscent lights, drab decor, and it being that you can hear the conversations of other diners within earshot. 

This place doesn't appear like a typical pho restaurant, which I thought was cool. The tables and setup seem post 90s instead of old school. There's also hiphop/rap music playing in the background, also a real good first for me.

I had the chicken soup. They use a wider type of pho noodle. Good, and after eyeing some other reviews I have no major complaints about the amount I received. The service was cool, not great or anything but I don't usually expect superior service when it comes to pho.

So yes, it earning my first pho review I like this place and will be back. Soon too, especially since it's been so cold lately.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Came here as an alternative to PPQ to avoid some of the crowds on Irving from the concert in the park, and was pleasantly surprised to see I could still get my usual order of Beef Satay pho here!

Having ordered myself a large bowl and imperial rolls to split with my friend, we eagerly awaited the arrival of our food.  Being a northern style restaurant, there were no beansprouts and mint leaves to drop in (which is fine since I don't think it would go well with this pho), but plenty of jalapenos and lime (which does go well).  Plus, rather than the usual pho noodles you would get, they give you the wider, flat noodles instead which was a nice change.  There was plenty of meat in the order, but the broth was just okay - it was less oily than PPQ's, but maybe that's why it seemed to be a little lighter on flavor and spice than what I'm used to.  As for the Imperial Rolls, they were a little disappointing not so much in the flavor/taste (crispy, not overly fried), but in the size of the rolls that you get for the price (1/2 to 2/3 the size of a roll at most places).  The accompaniment of vermicelli noodles on the side was nice though. 

Their menu isn't as expansive as other restaurants I've seen, but I imagine this is in part because it's a northern style restaurant.  They had a couple of chicken pho bowls on the menu, and even some oxtail plates which you don't see too often.  Okay alternative to my usual spots, but I'll still look towards PPQ first.
author: Mike L.

description: This review is based solely on their wine braised oxtail pho. It is out of this world delicious!! Huge chunks of carrot and large oxtail pieces float on the surface of this dark colored broth. Big pieces of ginger and star anise can be found as well as part of the complex seasoning. Not to be missed if you like oxtail. Will have to try their other pho options another time. I heard the duck pho is really good too.
author: Liz C.

description: I've been here before and it was ok but will not return. Tay Giang up the street is much better.  At almost every Vietnamese restaurant I go to I order the bun bowl with grilled pork and egg roll.  Today, the egg roll was greasy, the meat extremely fatty and a prize came in my bowl - a dirty old penny!  When I showed it to the server, she took it away and brought me a new bowl.  On a previous visit I had the pho which was good.  The service overall was so-so.  There are so many terrific Vietnamese restaurants in this city so no reason for me to return to this one.
author: Jamie K.

description:
this is one of MY favorite pho restaurants to go to. a lot of my friends actually don't like this place, i guess they dont like the taste of the broth or the type of noodles they use. 

i come here pretty often, mostly on Sundays with my family and we've gotten to know one of the waiters pretty well so he hooks it up with some good tea, the one in a teapot, not in a plastic cup.

i usually order a #10, raw and cooked beef noodle soup and i add extra limes and it makes it one heart meal. def. great after a drunken night of course. 

one downside is that parking sucks on noriega, and sometimes it gets pretty busy and its a small restaurant
author: Kenny L.

description:
This review is basically just to contradict what everyone else has said.

Basically the point here is that it is Northern Vietnamese style pho.  If you read the awning, it says Hanoi style.  Guess what, Hanoi is the birthplace of pho.  In the north, pho is served without sprouts and basil - just a slice of lime and sliced chilis.  Southern Vietnamese changed it up a little and started adding star anise to the broth - and also the bean sprouts and basil.  Guess who fled Viet Nam mostly during the war?  South Vietnamese.  That's why most all pho restaurants in the US are southern style.

Also, since when has packaged noodles become more welcome than freshly made noodles?  This place has soft, flat, thick noodles that go down like butta.  Why would you even want a choice?  And what would your choices be?  Egg noodle?  Come on.  It's like saying, "I can't believe I wasn't able to order a wheat sourdough bread."  The broth isn't overwhelmingly beefy, but atleast it's not fake MSG flavored like 95 percent of the pho restaurants in California.

I agree with Dawn that everyone has been brainwashed by bad pho joints!  This is one of the best out there.  It tastes like someone actually cooked up the bowl - instead of the flavor that all pho restaurants taste like.
author: Minkz N.

description:
Tried this place last night with my friend GW. I ordered the curry chicken with bread, GW ordered the chicken pho, and we shared the imperial rolls. The curry was so-so, decent. I thought the bread could've been crispier.. The chicken had alot of bones in it too, which I didn't like. I also thought the pho was ok.. not much taste.. I like Turtle Tower better. Also, the imperial rolls were really small and it didn't have much taste too. 

On the plus side, it was very clean and I thought the service was great. They did have rap music playing, but I didn't care.
author: C. T.

description: Great place for Pho, rice plates, and Vietnamese vermicelli dishes. Service could be a bit faster though.  The noodles in their Pho are the authentic kind of Pho.  Most people probably wouldn't know that.
author: Joe Y.

description:
We ended up here b/c I couldn't find Pho Garden.  I thought it was on Irving btw 22nd/23rd, then I thought no wait, it's on Taraval.  Still no luck, so I was like, I know there's this place on Noriega.  (I sure could have used an IPhone today.)

Good Northern style Pho.  I like the broth better than Turtle Tower's, but TT might give you more beef.  The broth here definitely has that homemade taste with a hint of ginger and even anise, even though northern style apparently doesn't use anise.  It's a pretty light broth, not much fish sauce or MSG, if they even use MSG.  

Their wide noodles weren't the best I've had, but still good.  The best wide noodles are still at Pho Ga Huong Que in Oakland.

Only garnishes were lime and jalapenos, scallions and cilantro are pre-added to the bowl.

The beef was fresh and dark, Tai was similar to Turtle Tower, pounded to tenderness.  Brisket was a little tougher but still ok.  

SO had 5 spice chicken over rice, and they use the same technique as PPQ on Irving sans MSG.
author: Derrick V.

description:
curry. chicken. pho.

i know you're thinking, "wtf? that doesnt even make sense" right? but wait till you get it. it's effing fantastic. i love this place so much you have no idea. the guys here know me by face. it's pretty embarrassing really, because when i try to order something else i have to make sure they heard me right. yeah, they know my order. 

also, the pho ga is one of the best in the city. the one at turtle tower is slightly bitter like they put ginseng in it or something. i don't dig that at all. this one is way better. trust.

also, their sizes are ridiculous. their small is a "large" anywhere else. their large is always "x-large". be warned. 

come here if you're a fan of delicious flavor.
author: Ben T.

description:
Known to me as "Little Window", I have been spoiled by this place. They previously owned "the Window" on Valencia. 

Not only are their northern vietnamese style pho is good, their beef balls are like the size of a tennis ball cut in half.  All their noodles/pho comes in small or large, but even their small bowl is a big serving.  Of course, Auntie Sarah always spoils me when I go there, so I cant really give a bad review.  But in all honesty, the food tastes yummy and the serving is good enough to fill me up.  You should definitely try out the fish cake and egg rolls as well as their Buen Yeuw (crab meat/tomato soup noodle) which is served with shrimp paste.

Hell...they even play hip-hop music in the background so that's different from any pho joints in the city.  If you can....try to watch the waiters karaoke-ing to the music.
author: Dave L.

description: There's style of noodles are a bit different here since the noodles here seemed a little more "big" (for a lack of a better term) than most of the other pho places I've eaten at.,The meat balls they give you are pretty big so if you complain about that, I don't know what to say. I can also listen to the latest commercial rap music on the radio too while I'm eating my pho. Makes me feel like I'm in a club, but not.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This was my first time trying Northern Vietnamese food.

LK got the firetruck (with huge beef balls) and I ordered the duck and bamboo shoot noodle soup. 

The broth was lovely and light with cilantro, onions, and lime. The duck was white! Well, white-ish. I'm so used to the fatty Chinese version that I was completely surprised to see duck so lean. 

I felt pretty healthy and proud of myself for eating such a light and lean meal even though I completely sucked up a large bowl of noodle soup. 

The bowls are big enough to wash a small baby.

Minus one star for the dirty cups. There was a "skin" of grime floating in my cup.

FYI they play 94.9 super loud during lunch on the weekdays. Cool if you like Fergie and Timbaland and (my personal favorite) Justin Timberlake.

*beep*beep*

UPDATE! January 27, 2008.

Today I ordered a small bowl of the rare beef with meatball soup. OH! The rare beef was so tender! So perfectly sliced! 

The beef ball was too big to really be enjoyed. I was kinda grossed out by the size. I had to take a bite, put it down, drink some soup, eat some noodle, and repeat. With two pieces of beef ball, I was chewing like that for a good, long while.  

MS ordered the chicken noodle soup which had tasty, boneless strips of white and dark meat. 

Both were excellent with the added lime. So elegantly simple. 

Tea cups still dirty.

*toot*toot*

UPDATE! March 9, 2008

Carpaccio is totally generous and fresh. The toppings are plentiful and tasty. 

But what I truly love, LOVE is the chicken salad. For less than $6 you can get a heaping plate of flavorful and fresh salad.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
My boyfriend & I came here about 3 weeks ago... & that was the last time we will be coming here ever again!

~Pros~

- Very good chicken salad

~Cons~

- RUDE & BAD customer service! * We were done eating & wanted the bill to pay. The restaurant was getting fairly crowded so we wanted to leave to give our table to other customers coming in. There were 2 workers, (1 male & 1 female), wandering around. My boyfriend flagged down the male worker & asked for the bill & he gave us an "ok". We were waiting for about 5 minutes watching him do other stuff besides getting our bill. Apparently, there were 3 guys waiting outside for a table (I guess the regulars) and the male worker quickly set up their table, gave them special cups ( customers usually get the tall nasty plastic cup, but these guys get the Chinese ceramic cups)  & a tea pot for the table. After that, the worker started chatting up with the regulars while we were waiting for our bills. It's like we don't exist anymore... Being fed up with that crappy service, I waved down the female worker & asked for the bill, she quickly gave us the bill, but there was no amount on it! I was like " Cool.. free meal!" We could have easily gotten up & left because they weren't paying attention to anyone! But my boyfriend made me tell the female worker..  so I flagged her down & told her "You didn't write an amount" She was like " Oh, ok." She quickly took the bill & just wrote "$15.95" & rudely handed the bill back to us.. so we just paid it & left. Closed the door & NEVER coming back!

- The tea tasted weird... tasted like soap. I don't think they wash their dishes all too well! GROSS!!!

- CASH ONLY! Not everyone carries cash shoot!!!!

To end my long review, this place is OVER-HYPED!!!  NOT RECOMMENDED!!! If you are craving Northern Vietnam Pho, like me, I recommend  Green Bamboo on Noriega (19th).. it has the same flat noodles or request the normal pho type noodles, & gives you the basil & bean spouts!!
author: Selina L.

description:
Pho in the Sunset is actually difficult to find.
Good pho in the Sunset is damn near impossible to find.

Wifey and I eat out a lot.  When we computed the statistics, Viet cuisine came out on top with an average of 2.2 visits per week... that's a lot of pho.  Now we ain't picky, we know the score in SF and we're well aware that Viet is one of the few cuisines that's sub-par in the city.  Unless you're willing to troll the restaurants in the Tenderloin,  San Jose is the closest you're going to get to decent Viet.

That said, we're still happy to find a new noodle joint that's somewhat close to our house.  As others have mentioned, the menu's painfully short.  But who cares as long as the food is decent and prices are cheap, right?

The place is small, but decor is above average as far as Vietnamese joints go.  Prices are similar to what other places charge and I like that because nothing pisses me off more than someone trying to sell me a $10 bowl of pho.

Try the tomato and crab paste noodle for something different.

Oh yeah, this place is CASH ONLY.  I forgot my wallet the day we went  but I managed to convince the owners to let the wifey work off our debt by washing dishes and cleaning their toilet.  She didn't smell too good when I picked her up later that evening...
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Went back to try their Chicken Noodle Soup. Not too bad my second time around. The noodles were thicker cut than other pho places, but this is a "different pho" place. The broth didn't have overwhelming MSG or salt which was a plus. The chicken was good if eaten quickly, but i let some of my pieces sit, thus making it tough. Overall, I prefer this over turtle tower (surprised?). Cheap, good portions and endless napkins.

The tea (cups) had a soapy oder and was watered down to the point where I couldn't taste the tea very much. Service was a bit spotty, but this isn't that type of place.
author: Tim S.

description:
YUCK!  one of the worst Vietnamese noodle soup I've had in my life.  the broth was just awful.  it was missing some key ingredients and it tasted watered down.  i figured that this place was going to be good since it seemed to be packed when ever i walked by, but was i wrong.   i haven't tired the rice plates..so perhaps it is better than the noodle soup.

Stick to Turtle Tower if you're craving for Northern Vietnamese style pho.
author: hello k.

description:
So, I don't know pho very well...pity, because I LOVE it.  Maybe after I've been to a few more places I will return and change this review, but for now, this little place is my favorite.  The broth is amazing, the noodles the perfect size (about 1/4" wide, but thin), and just enough meat for me.  I always get the rare beef, it's delicious and I would be willing to pay far beyond the price tag (which I think is like $6) for it.  I've never been able to finish a bowl and neither has anyone I know with the exception of my little brother, and we totally thought he was going to ralph.

I had to take away a star for their unforgivably smelly bathroom (which I understand is not entirely their fault, but purchasing a can of lysol would not be out of the question.)
author: Jasmine L.

description: pretty good for a local Pho place but not a huge fan of the noodles and the service isn't very good.
author: Kristen M.

description:
One place I wanted to try for awhile and finally had the chance to when a couple of my friends suggested it...  

They had mentioned their large meatballs here.  I do believe that might be their signature here...  

Not the best, not the worse...
author: Mark W.

description:
First time I tried this place, I was like "no sprouts!" WTF  But, I actually don't mind it.  I've been here about a dozen time already, and the food is usually pretty consistent, and FAST.  If you order pho, it will hit your table in less than 5 mins.  The broth for the Pho is quite tasty, both the beef  and the chicken broth.  And they put plenty of green onions and cilantro, if you like that stuff.  I usually get the well done and rare beef, and beef ball Pho, large!  The rare beef is tender and tasty.  I think one of the things I like best is the wide Pho noodles, which resembles the wider Chinese Ho Fun.  It has a nice soft texture and is easy to eat, and they give a alot of it.  So, if you can finish a large bowl of that, then you're pretty hungry.

Their pricing is average, service is good, and the atmosphere is decent.  I will definitely continue eating here, as my business is nearby.

My only gripe is that the chopsticks are so darn small, they give me hand cramps when I'm done.  Bigger chopsticks, please!
author: Crosby C.

description: I didnt like the type of noodle in the pho because whenever i came its the thicker kind you know? Service is fine. small joint. Parking is not too hard, luckily.it is not like Irving ha ha
author: Veranna N.

description:
I was initially disappointed with the lack of bean sprouts and basil, but the noodles (wide! fresh! slurpy!) and the broth (thin! not too oily! presumably MSG-free!) more than made up for it.  Plus, North Vietnamese pho isn't served with the same condiments, so they're authentic to boot. 
I had the #6, with thin slices of beef and onion.  Added plenty of lime.
The waiter and family (?) are nice, the food is good, the music is predictably bad KMEL jams.    
I haven't been to PPQ or the other spot on Irving in a while.  If you live in the Sunset and you want a good bowl that's different than the MSG-loaded pho joints around here, check out Quan Ngon.
author: Nick H.

description:
Came yesterday after a dying pho craving, but left a little disappointed. I really wanted beef pho with tendons, but there was no such thing on the menu. 

I ordered the well done & rare beef pho instead, and my boyfriend ask for only rare beef pho, and in about 3 minutes we got our food. FAST (should I worry?). There are no usual side condiments like mint, cilantro, etc, but only a meesy sauce dish of jalapenos and lime. 

The noodles they use here are thick, which again, did not really match my pho craving pho noodles. Oh well, I don't mind much. The soup here was a little bland though. The weird thing was, that my boyfriend and I essentially got the same dish, and it came out super fast, leaving us believe it was the same soup base. However, his bowl was more flavorful (he claimed it was a little on the bitter side) and mine was bland. 

The good thing is, the bowls were big! We ordered a large, and I could barely finish half (leaving me with dinner all figured out!)!

But another not-so-appropriate thing is, I saw a Caucasian lady come in and say, "I heard you guys have good chicken noodles. I'll have one to go" and then she asked for the price, and the man at the cashier just told her the price of the large bowl, without asking her which size she preferred. It would have been better if he offered her the option of small or large; she was a small lady and it was her first time trying it, so she might not have wanted a large to start out with.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I was debating between 1 and 2 stars. I think 1 stars shall be reserved for restaurants that have wronged me. 2 stars will be for sucky restaurants that while have no redeeming qualities, did not upset me. 

I came here for the chicken pho, and I was so disappointed. I guess it's not fair to compare to Turtle Tower, but after TT, I could not eat what they served here at Pho Quan Ngon. You know TT's chicken pho has that special je ne sais quoi to it? That special taste in their soup? Well not only does this place not have it in their soup, their soup tastes like nothing...nothing except MSG and onions. Every bite contained more onions, green and yellow, than actual noodles. The soup tasted like canned chicken broth with a sh!tload of onions. I can never eat here again after having the delicious chicken pho from the TT in Tenderloin.

Oh, and I saw the waiter walk into the bathroom a few times, leaving me wondering if he remembered to wash his hands afterwards before dipping his thumb into my soup as he carried it out.
author: Jessie C.

description:
I like this pho restaurant!!  For a small, hole in the wall joint, it has FAST FAST service, excellent noodles, and great rare steak and meatballs.  The chicken salad is also a major plus and a great appetizer to share or eat as a main course for a healthy alternative to a big bowl of noodles.

Yes, it's Northern Vietnamese cuisine, so it's not your conventional pho restaurant.  I really like the flat rice noodles that they serve (versus the regular pho noodles at all the other Vietnamese restaurants in the city).  And contrary to the previous talks about the broth, etc., I like the broth!  It's good!  It's a bummer that there are no bean sprouts, but I'm happy with my siracha sauce and Hosin sauce.  Not an expert at pho, but I do enjoy this restaurant!
author: Steph M.

description:
At Vietnamese places, I've normally been a rice-plate kind of guy ... until now. I don't know what inspired me to go pho, but I'm now a convert.

Beef pho. The slices are delicious, and the broth is awesome.

Standard caveats for parking in this 'hood apply.
author: Rob T.

description: Chicken pho! Crab & tomato pho! Satay pho! Northern Vietnamese style pho served without basil & bean sprouts, just lime and jalapeño. They use the flat, wide rice noodles.
author: P K.

description: A change in taste from the norm (love PPQ), the ho-fun type noodle and lack of msg makes it the third type of noodle soup I crave.  The other being the #1 from PPQ and then the Chew Jow Ho Fun at Vien Huong in Oakland.
author: Max L.

description: I had a pretty enjoyable bowl of noodle recently.  I ordered the one with chicken and the parts in it.  The soup was fairly good, making it a good place to go for this type in the Sunset.  They also have pretty big pieces of chicken liver (I'm into that but I know many people aren't).  It's better than what I recall of the beef-based soup bowls when I came before.
author: H K.

description:
if your looking for a good crab soup, "bun rie " this place makes a very good one. Loi's in Irving makes a good bowl but it is too greasy and has hardly any crab balls.  I've tried almost evrything on their simple but yet good menu. I would have given this place a five star if it wasn't for their annoying hip hop music, lack of service and those stupid smokers outside their joint.
can't wait for smokers ban on all sf restaurant
author: ramon L.

description: Disappointing. First off, I had weird things moving around in my tea. It was so gross that I didn't touch it. Then came the soup. It looked okay. It didn't look like something I was used to since they didn't bring any bean sprouts and the noodles were a little thicker than normal. My girlfriend ordered Satay, but asked for pho noodles. Of course, she got some other thin noodles. We both then tasted the soup. Unfortunately, both of our bowls were just lukewarm. It was so cold that the rare beef inside of the soup didn't even cook. I don't think I'll head back here again.
author: Alton Y.

description: I really like this place. Great pho at the right price. Their onions and limes were fresh and juicy, which made me happy. I had no problem with their service. In my opinion, I think its much better than Tay Giang.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Bad value for your money. Order the noodle soup. While waiting for the order, they poor tea with a moth or was a it bug in my tea floating around and I told them and they said oh ok and just got me another one as if it's normal to have bugs in people's tea.

I order the beef noodle soup. It's basically some noodles, beef and some soup, as if they just made it at home, paid about $7 for it.

Cup o noodles tastes better. 

If you come here you are asking for it.
author: Robin T236532i9 W.

description:
A bowl of Pho is $5.50-$6.50 which is reasonable. The broth is great and meat is extremely extremely tender. Very good quality. 

Echoing the other reviews, don't come here if you expect the typical pho with basil and bean sprouts. 

The vietnamese ice coffee with milk is VERY strong and i'm still buzzing from it 5 hours later....

Service is fast but i ate at a weird hour when business was slow. And there is no ambience. but overall, i'm satisfied. 4 stars for the meat...i'm very impressed.
author: Marcia O.

description:
*Disclaimer - I didn't know this was a Northern Vietnamese restaurant.

So my friends were raving about this pho place that they refer to as "that Noriega purple pho place." Well, today I finally got to try it.

The good:
- Wasn't used to the thicker but still thin sized noodles for pho, but that's okay. I'm a lover of all noodles. (Wasn't aware that this was the way Northern Vietnamese pho was like until my friend told me. Interesting.) It was delicious none the less.

- I requested that they take the beef balls out and they did just that. I love it when restaurants listen to your requests without asking any questions.

- Super heart that they only brought out jalapenos and limes. I don't put anything but limes in my pho. And I feel really bad when I go to other Vietnamese restaurants and they bring out a fat plate of herbs when all I wanted were limes.

Why two stars:
- Minimal menu. There wasn't much to choose from. I kind of felt like I curbed my appetite to suit the menu.

- 6.95 for a regular sized bowl? Seriously? Maybe I'm jaded by other restaurants where a MEDIUM bowl is 6.95.

- Today was a hot ass day. On a hot ass day, we were served a steaming hot ass cup of water. A glass cup.

I know it doesn't seem like a lot of justification for two stars, but just those impressions had me at SERIOUSLY?

I am willing to give this place another shot, though.
author: Sandy L.

description: Their Pho is some of the best I've had in awhile. The broth is amazing and the meat is on point. Everything tasted fresh and the food came fairly quickly. The service wasn't the greatest, but to their credit the place was packed when I went. I'll take rushed service for bomb food any day.
author: Marissa G.

description: my friend took me here to try something different than our usual ppq nearby.. first time trying northern pho ga and liked it..(i haven't even been to turtle tower yet!-shocking i know, i am too).. i love that the noodles are thicker and have a bit of texture.. the broth was hot and wasn't bad at all.. overall, i had a good experience here and wouldn't mind going back here again
author: Raquel T.

description: brand new pho (Vietnamese noodle) house. the key to good pho is the broth. it should be served piping hot and have enough flavor and seasoning to carry the meal. the noodles served with the soup must be fresh. and the really good places offer a variety of noodles with the choice of beef or chicken broth. this pho house has a good, not great soup but strangely enough did not offer a choice of noodles. or the traditional bean sprouts, jalapeno, fresh basil on the side.  we all had the broad noodles today. and on top of this lack of choice, they were sold out of cha gio (Imperial rolls) on a Sunday lunch hour! the place was jammed pack for lunch so it may be worth a second visit to see if they've worked out the kinks. potential is there; but not much execution yet.
author: Jeff W.

description:
This too was my first time trying the Northern Vietnamese pho, it was good, but I think I have programed myself to crave the more common version of pho.  The broth that was in the rare/well cooked beef pho was tasty, it didn't really need the extras, however I think I prefer the egg noodles or thinner rice noodles.  The bun dish I had was tasty....the pork was nice and crispy grilled.

The service was wonderful, the woman who was taking care of the tables was incredibly attentive.  I would try it again when I wasn't craving the other pho.
author: Brye L.

description: Good chicken Pho here (Pho Ga), which is rare.  Normally Pho places are all beef pho joints.  Broth is not as good as my home made,  but it's definitely good compared to other places you eat Pho at.
author: Bob D.

description:
As Vietnam's native son, I do not really go to Vietnamese restaurants for 2 reasons.  

1.  Homemade pho is the best; the broth is rich and drinkable 
2.  My mother's cuisine is rather americanized and my 5 day diet is literally this: potatoes,chicken/steak/potatoes, chicken/pasta/pasta.  Maybe once a month will I get a bowl of pho.  

However, driving back from Carmel, it was a bit dreary outside and I needed some of that warm liquid to warm up my innards.  I came in with my concubine and we both ordered pho ba vien.  Usually I always get the #1, but lately I have been getting the meatballs b/c it was a staple of my childhood when my mother was in her cooking prime.  Now, as old age sets in, she is slacking on her duties and the molding of meatballs into those perfect spheres are no longer available in the vu household.  I miss the old days of savoring the meatballs, biting and splitting the meatball into 2's so you can spare some for the end meal.  Pho Quan Ngon is a northern vietnamese style place and that is the type I like more.  There is sparse condiments.  The noddles are a little thicker.  To give a better analogy, think a hot dog without the ketchup/mustard/relish or a hamburger without the buns.  Har har...i digress.  The service is lightening fast...like click our heels 3 times fast.  I ordered, blinked, and my food was set besides me.  This pho joint is run by genies.  The pho is good.  It has a rather greasy sheen to it, but the meatballs were good and the noodles soft.  My girlfriend ordered the beef carpaccio, which was the first time I had raw beef ever.  It was not to my liking.  It was sweet and had a weird taste.

To bid you adieu, pho quan ngon is a no nonsense pho joint.  You go in there, scratch your left food with your other foot, and slurp your pho.  The only downside is that is is cash only so I suggest you sit near the door if you intend to eat n ditch.  But please, keep it rieu and do not be a bad human being unless there are dire circumstances where you must avoid the bill.
author: Brian V.

description: SATAY BEEF NOODLE SOUP. THE BEST. That is all I order whenever I come here before work. Soup base is good and I always find parking on the residential streets because I refuse to pay meter parking.
author: Willa L.

description:
The last time I ate something from here was a disaster. I found a foreign object in my egg roll. It was huge, hard, and black. I have been scarred ever since and will not eat egg rolls from here ever again.

Before this experience, I actually liked this Vietnamese noodle joint. It was new and close by. It's pretty small inside, not much seating. Nothing much to hate about though.

I will give this an update after eating here again, but until then, yuck!
author: Winnie L.

description:
Every time I visit this place (no matter dine-in or to-go), I can't resist their crab meat noodles in tomato soup.  Honestly, so far I have only tried a few of their selections (coz I just can't beat their crab meat), I could only recommend this.

And I love the cabbage (only) in the tomato soup.  It makes me not hate the cabbage as usual, and I could eat all stuff in the bowl, remaining just little tomato soup.

I don't care about bean sprouts, as I finally find something better than that!
author: Woodspy T.

description:
Ordered two dishes to-go. 

 #1.  Their famous Chicken Pho:  
I always order the beef Pho when i go to vietnamese restaurant.  A chicken Pho for a difference for the first time added some points.  Despite the bit saltyness.  It was actually not bad.   

#2. The chicken salad:
It was soaked with sauce.  Don't enjoyed as much.   I don't know if it would make a difference, if i didn't take to-go for that.  

Service-wise, i am not super impressed.  Two waiters were there, both of them didn't seem too friendly.  They actually messed up my order  giving me two pho, instead of one pho and one salad.  When I asked them again, just to double check if it is correct, they seemed very impatient.
author: Jasmin Y.

description: Came here with my family tonight and the service was beyond horrible. We ordered two small chicken noodle soup, two big chicken noodle soup, and vietnamese carpaccio. Waited 35 minutes to get our noodles and during our wait customers came in at 8:30pm and were rudely told that they were closed because there was no more food when the open sign was still placed at the window. After we received our noodles we noticed that the portions were the same and that there were only two pieces of chicken in our noodles. We asked the waitress and she said there was no more food, which she never mentioned in the beginning or we would have all ordered small. As we were finishing our noodles we asked about our carpaccio she told us that if we wanted it we would have to wait another 20 minutes! There was no one in the restaurant so we did not understand why it would take so long to prepare raw beef! We cancelled our order and the waitress walked away without even apologizing. At the end she also added 15% tip to the bill without telling us. Never coming back here.
author: Lorraine N.

description: I've come here a couple of times since my first review and each time I've confirmed that the pho here did not taste as good as I thought it did the first time. I still really like the soft noodles that come with the broth but taste wise I would go a couple of doors down instead. This would still be an alternative for us if we go on a day when the other place is closed though.
author: Helen L.

description: I ordered a number 12 and it was awesome! although the noodles are different (ho fun) not the pho noodles i still enjoyed it and devour that bowl of pho with satisfaction.  The soup was good. But pricing it's a bit on the pricey side for pho.  i did not mind because it was delicious! I will definitely pay a visit here again if i am around the neighborhood!
author: Ann L.
